The original call number for Lieut. Bull Head in Police Uniform, Yanktonai Dakota is AP 629b, Box 39. The original call number for Red Tomahawk (Dakota Indian), ca. 1853-1931 is AP 629c, Box 39. The original title of AP 629c is "Red Tomahawk, Yanktonai Dakota."

rdf:Description.dc:title: Standing Buffalo, Chief, ca. 1833-1871
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Whitney, Joel E. (Joel Emmons), 1822-1886
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Santee Indians; Standing Buffalo, Chief, approximately 1833-1871
rdf:Description.dc:description: Portrait photograph of Standing Buffalo, a Sioux chief. Printed below photograph,"A hereditary Chief of the Sioux and a Participator in the Massacre of 1862, in Minnesota. Entered according to Act of Congress, by J.E. Whitney, in the year 1862, in the Clerk's Office of the U.S. District Court for Minnesota."Whitney's Gallery Saint Paul." Title on original "Ta-Tanka-Nazin (Standing Buffalo), Dakota." See also AP 525, Box 36 and AP 3064, Box 76.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Cut Nose
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Whitney, Joel E. (Joel Emmons), 1822-1886
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Santee Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Card stock photo of the Dakota Indian chief Cut Nose, who, along with 37 other Dakota Indians, was hanged in Mankato, Minnesota, on December 26, 1862, for taking part in attacks on white settlers and communities in Minnesota in 1862. Printed on mount, "Who in the Massacre of 1862, in Minnesota, murdered 18 Women and Children and 5 Men.", "Entered according to Act of Congress, by J.E. rdf:Description.dc:description: Portrait photograph of Pa-da-ne A-pa-pe (Struck by the Ree). Title, provenance and biographical information written on the verso of photograph in pencil and ink. Written on verso of photograph, "Sometimes called - 'Mato Ne Chacksha' or 'Old Bear'. He was the Head Chief of the Yankton Sioux Indians - Scout Bands - Died at 92 years of age. He was justly honored and esteemed by all who knew him." "Struck by the Ree was born when Lewis and Clark were being entertained by the Sioux in camp at Greene Island, Yankton, Sept., 1804. When Capt. Lewis heard of his birth in one of the Indian lodges, he sent for the child and wrapped it in the American flag and made a speech in which he prophesied he would become eminent among his people and a great friend to the white men. He became head chief of the Yankton Sioux and was probably the means of saving the entire settlement at Yankton from massacre in the 'War of the Outbreak' in 1863. See Brief History of South Dakota by Doane Robertson."
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 portrait photograph; image 13.5 x 18.7 cm; on sheet 25.3 x 30.6 cm Albumen prints; Photographs; Portraits jpeg
rdf:Description.dc:relation: Edward E. Ayer Photograph Collection (Newberry Library) Edward E. Ayer Digital Collection (Newberry Library)

rdf:Description.dc:title: Comienca un exercicio en lengua mexicana sacado del Sancto Evango. y distribuido por todos los dias de la semana Exercisios quotidianos en lengua mexicana
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Sahagn, Bernardino de, -1590
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Catholic Church; Liturgics; Bible. Gospels; Church year meditations; Lord's Supper; Manuscripts, Nahuatl
rdf:Description.dc:description: Contemporary copy of Father Bernardino de Sahagn's 1574 correction and reworking of an anonymous compilation of Biblical readings and meditations in Nahuatl. An introductory section of five pages is followed by meditations based on readings from the Gospels for each day of the week, beginning with Monday. Themes from the readings include the angel's announcement of the birth of Christ to the shepherds; the young Jesus teaching the elders in the temple; and Christ establishing the sacrament of Holy Communion. The tri-lingual meditation on the Eucharist contains the liturgy in Latin, followed by Spanish glosses, and explanations in Nahuatl of the ceremony and its significance.
rdf:Description.dc:format: [86] p., bound ; 23 cm. Manuscripts; Devotional literature Tiff

rdf:Description.dc:title: Siguense veynte y seis addiciones desta postilla Doctrina christiana en mexicano; Nican vnpeoa yn nemachtiliz tlatolli
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Sahagn, Bernardino de, -1590
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Catholic Church; Theology, Doctrinal; Theological virtues; Religion; Nahuas; Indians of Mexico; Manuscripts, Nahuatl
rdf:Description.dc:description: Two copies of Sahagn's earlier "addiciones" to the Postilla, a textual fragment of a larger series of admonitions, and a concluding appendix added in 1579. 1486A and 1486B are both copies of the additions: 1486A, entitled "Nican vnpeoa yn nemachtiliz tlatolli," is the complete version, signed by Sahagn, with titles and text in Nahuatl, and "cut and paste" corrections; while 1486B is incomplete, with titles in Spanish. The additions explain the three theological virtues: Faith (ch. 1-3), Hope (ch. 4), and Charity (ch. 5-9). Chapters 11-24 concern specific examples of the virtues, such as charity towards one's neighbors; charity towards oneself; love of one's enemies; and neighborly love. The final three chapters describe the punishments of hell; the rewards of virtue in the glories of heaven; and death and the day of judgment. The fragment of text accompanying the appendix (1486C) contains moral and doctrinal admonitions or "tenonotzaliztli," condemning native rituals. The appendix (1486D), copied by one of Sahaguns scribes, Alonso Vegerano, also condemns Indian religious beliefs, with special emphasis on the role of the devil in Indian life.
rdf:Description.dc:format: [90] p.; 31 cm Manuscripts; Marbled calf bindings (Binding) Tiff

rdf:Description.dc:title: Siguense unos sermones de dominicas y de santos en lengua mexicana
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Sahagn, Bernardino de, -1590
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Catholic Church; Sermons, Nahuatl; Saints; Church year sermons; Festival-day sermons; Manuscripts, Nahuatl
rdf:Description.dc:description: Compilation of sermons in Nahuatl by Father Bernardino Sahagn, begun in 1540, and revised and corrected in 1563. The cycle of Sunday sermons for the church year is incomplete, beginning with the first Sunday in Advent, and concluding with the 19th Sunday after Pentecost and a single sermon for the last Sunday before Advent. There are four selections for each Sunday: a meditation on a reading from the Gospels, introduced by a one-line quote in Latin; and three sermons, to be given on a rotating basis. The cycle of sermons for saints' days, the "Santoral" which begins on page 181, is also incomplete, containing sermons in honor of only a few saints, Sts. Andrew, Thomas, Stephen, and John.
rdf:Description.dc:format: [196] p., bound: maguey paper; 40 cm Sermons; Manuscripts; Limp bindings (Binding); Leather bindings (Binding) Tiff

rdf:Description.dc:title: Incipiunt Epistolae et Evangelia, quae in diebus dominicis per anni totius circulum leguntur Incipiu[n]t Ep[isto]l[a]e et Eva[n]gelia, qu[a]e in diebus dominicis p[er] anni totius circulum legu[n]t[u]r; Lectionary. Nahuatl; Bible. Epistles. Nahuatl; Bible. Gospels. Nahuatl
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Catholic Church
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Bible. Epistles; Bible. Gospels; Church year meditations; Manuscripts, Nahuatl
rdf:Description.dc:description: Sixteenth-century lectionary based on the New Testament Gospels and Epistles to be used during Sunday services and on feast days throughout the church year, translated from Latin into Nahuatl, possibly by Father Alonso de Molina or Father Bernardino de Sahagn. Readings begin with the first Sunday in Advent, and continue through the seasons of the church year, including Epiphany, Lent, the Passion season, Easter, and Pentecost. Readings are also given for celebrating feast days such as the Purification of the Virgin, the Anunciation, and the Invention of the Holy Cross, as well as the feast days of important Catholic saints such as Sebastian, Mark, and Barnabas. Decorated initials; Nahuatl text in black ink; Latin headings in red.
rdf:Description.dc:contributor: Molina, Alonso de, -1585; Sahagn, Bernardino de, -1590
rdf:Description.dc:format: [4], 552, [3] p. ; 15 cm. Lectionaries; Liturgical lessons; Manuscripts; Leather bindings (Binding) Tiff

rdf:Description.dc:title: Assiniboin Indians
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Bodmer, Karl, 1809-1893
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Assiniboine Indians; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Indian weapons; Quillwork; Shields; Rifles; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Tableau 32 in atlas: Illustrations to Maximilian, Prince of Wied's Travels in the interior of North America. Portrait of two Assiniboine men. Pitapiu, at right wears a rawhide shield with an amulet, a whip hangs from his wrist. His hair is loose and he wears red face paint. The man at left wears a quilled, beaded shirt with leather fringe and he carries a gun. In 1836 Maximilian commissioned Bodmer to create illustrations to accompany the text of his atlas documenting their travels. These illustrations include 81 plates of aquatints.

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Geronimo, 1829-1909; Chiricahua Indians; Kings and rulers; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Profile portrait of Geronimo, famous Chiricahua Apache warrior and tribal leader. Side view of seated Geronimo wrapped in red blanket and wearing red fabric headwrap. Burbank, travelling through the American West for two decades, painted and drew individuals from more than 125 tribes. Framed oil painting on canvas.

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mandan Indians; Manners and customs; Dwellings; Boats and boating; Rivers Birds
rdf:Description.dc:description: Tableau 16 in atlas: Illustrations to Maximilian, Prince of Wied's Travels in the interior of North America. Landscape depiction of the summer village, Mih-Tutta-Hangkusch, a village of earth lodges high above cliffs overlooking the Missouri River, near Fort Clark. Mandan women are depicted here with their bullboats on the Missouri River. In 1836 Maximilian commissioned Bodmer to create illustrations to accompany the text of his atlas documenting their travels. These illustrations include 81 plates of aquatints.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Massika, Saki Indian and Wakusasse, Musquake Indian
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Bodmer, Karl, 1809-1893
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Sauk Indians; Clothing and dress; Fox Indians Roach headdresses
rdf:Description.dc:description: Tableau 3 in atlas: Illustrations to Maximilian, Prince of Wied's Travels in the interior of North America. Portrait of Massika, a Saki (Sac or Sauc) Indian and Wakusassa, a Musquake (Fox) Indian. Massika wears beaded earrings, a roach headdress and facial markings depicting bear claw marks, a denotation of his tribal identity. Wakusasse wears a roach headdress, beads and face paint. In 1836 Maximilian commissioned Bodmer to create illustrations to accompany the text of his atlas documenting their travels. These illustrations include 81 plates of aquatints.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Indian Utensils and arms
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Bodmer, Karl, 1809-1893
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Implements, utensils, etc.; Indian weapons; Weapons; Bow and arrow; Lances; Drum
rdf:Description.dc:description: Tableau 48 in atlas: Illustrations to Maximilian, Prince of Wied's Travels in the interior of North America. Variety of objects collected by Prince Maximillian, from the Plains Indian tribal communities. Objects include Sioux and Iroquois moccasins, quill-decorated otter skin, bows, an eagle-feather war bonnet, a double-goose-bone war whistle, a hair roach, a Sioux pipe, painted rawhide storage bag, a Mandan hoop-and-pole game item, a lance, a pipe temper, ceremonial drum, pipe with eagle feathers, cloth, horsehair and woodpecker bills, a stone knife and an elaborate warshield, and medicine bundles. In 1836 Maximilian commissioned Bodmer to create illustrations to accompany the text of his atlas documenting their travels. These illustrations include 81 plates of aquatints.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 drawing; 44 x 60 cm Aquatints; Works of art Tiff
rdf:Description.dc:source: London: Ackermann and Co. rdf:Description.dc:title: Indian Utensils and arms
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Bodmer, Karl, 1809-1893
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Implements, utensils, etc.; Indian weapons; Weapons
rdf:Description.dc:description: Tableau 21 in atlas: Illustrations to Maximilian, Prince of Wied's Travels in the interior of North America. Collection of items owned by Prince Maximilian. Depicted items include a painted bison hide or robe illustrated with military exploits of Mandan chief, Mato-Tope. Pipe of Mandan warrior-chief Dipauch, an ermine skin pounch, an elk-antler quirt, a bird-bone war whistle thought to belong to Mato-Tope, an otter-skin pouch with quillwork and beads, a tobacco pouch from skin of a white skunk, a "conquest bundle" (Hidatsa), a knife and sheath, and a Mandan snowshoe. In 1836 Maximilian commissioned Bodmer to create illustrations to accompany the text of his atlas documenting their travels. These illustrations include 81 plates of aquatints.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Missouri Indian, Oto Indian, Chief of the Puncas
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Bodmer, Karl, 1809-1893
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Ponca Indians; Clothing and dress; Oto Indians; Missouri Indians; Indian beadwork
rdf:Description.dc:description: Tableau 7 in atlas: Illustrations to Maximilian, Prince of Wied's Travels in the interior of North America. Portraits of a Missouri Indian, Oto Indian, and Chief of the Puncas. The Puca Chief, named Schuh-De-Ga-Che or "He-Who-Smokes", is wearing a large peace medal on a string with the image of U.S. President James Madison. The Oto Indian is wearing a small padlock attached to a beaded necklace. The Missouri Indian named Mahinkacka or "Maker of Knives" is wearing a choker and earrings of "wampum" beads and a commercial or trade blanket. The other men are wearing traditional buffalo-hide skins. In 1836 Maximilian commissioned Bodmer to create illustrations to accompany the text of his atlas documenting their travels. These illustrations include 81 plates of aquatints.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 drawing; 44 x 60 cm Aquatints; Portraits; Works of art Tiff

rdf:Description.dc:description: Tableau 19 in atlas: Illustrations to Maximilian, Prince of Wied's Travels in the interior of North America. rdf:Description.dc:title: Chief Po-Ka-Gon, Pottawattomie
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Burbank, E. A. (Elbridge Ayer), 1858-1949
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Pokagon, Simon, 1830-1899; Potawatomi Indians; Clothing and dress; Kings and rulers; Pokagon, Simon, 1830-1899
rdf:Description.dc:description: Portrait of Chief Pokagon of the Potawatomi Indians. Frontal view from the waist up, partial profile view of left side. Chief Pokagon is pictured in work clothes of a tan shirt with a lace-up closure. "Chief Po-Ka-Gon. Pottawattamie." written in red paint on upper left corner. Signed "E.A. Burbank. Lee, Mic. 1898." in brown paint in lower right corner. Unframed oil painting on canvas. Burbank, travelling through the American West for two decades, painted and drew individuals from more than 125 tribes.

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Rivers; Trees; Birds
rdf:Description.dc:description: Tableau 5 in atlas: Illustrations to Maximilian, Prince of Wied's Travels in the interior of North America. View from a densely wooded island, overlooking the estuary of Fox River into the Wabash River. An eagle is perched on a branch and birds (Carolina parakeets) fly overhead. Sycamore trees are identified and a boat is in the far distance. In the right foreground, cows or cattle graze along the riverbank. In 1836 Maximilian commissioned Bodmer to create illustrations to accompany the text of his atlas documenting their travels. These illustrations include 81 plates of aquatints.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mato-Tope, A Mandan Chief
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Bodmer, Karl, 1809-1893
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Mandan Indians; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Indian beadwork Headdresses
rdf:Description.dc:description: Tableau 13 in atlas: Illustrations to Maximilian, Prince of Wied's Travels in the interior of North America. Portrait of Mandan Chief, Mato-Tope or "Four Bears". He wears a shirt made of bighorn sheepskin, adorned with ermine tails, locks of hair, quillwork outlined in beads. He wears a large headdress with eagle feathers The red markings on his skin have been identified as old war wounds and the symbols on his shoulder represent brave deads. He holds a lance in his right hand. In 1836 Maximilian commissioned Bodmer to create illustrations to accompany the text of his atlas documenting their travels. These illustrations include 81 plates of aquatints.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 drawing; 55.5 x 44 cm Aquatints; Portraits; Works of art Tiff

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Bodmer, Karl, 1809-1893
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indian women; Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Face painting
rdf:Description.dc:description: Tableau 33 in atlas: Illustrations to Maximilian, Prince of Wied's Travels in the interior of North America. Portrait of two Plains Indian women. The woman of the Snake Tribe, at left, wears a hide dress with fringe, and a purple cloth blanket. The Cree woman, at right wears an elk hide dress, a trade blanket, red face paint, and elaborate earrings made of dentalium shells and blue beads. Her hair is in braids. In 1836 Maximilian commissioned Bodmer to create illustrations to accompany the text of his atlas documenting their travels. These illustrations include 81 plates of aquatints.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mato-Tope, Adorned with the insignia of his warlike deeds.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Bodmer, Karl, 1809-1893
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mandan Indians; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Indian weapons Headdresses
rdf:Description.dc:description: Tableau 14 in atlas: Illustrations to Maximilian, Prince of Wied's Travels in the interior of North America. Portrait of Mato-Tope, with emphasis on his accomplishments in battle. His headdress consists of 6 sticks that are symbols of war wounds, coup feathers, and a large turkey feather that represents an injury from an arrow. The owl feather cluster mens he is a member of the prestigious Dog Society. The stripes on his right arm commemorate feats of war, and the yellow hand painted on his chest signifies that he captured prisioners. In 1836 Maximilian commissioned Bodmer to create illustrations to accompany the text of his atlas documenting their travels. These illustrations include 81 plates of aquatints.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 drawing; 55.5 x 44 cm Aquatints; Works of art Tiff

rdf:Description.dc:description: Tableau 17 in atlas: Illustrations to Maximilian, Prince of Wied's Travels in the interior of North America. Portrait of Pehriska-Ruhpa in Minitari dance costume decorated with elaborate quillwork, ermine fur fringe, locks of human hair and dyed hoarsehair. His necklace is otter skin decorated with small trade beads and grizzly bear claws. He holds a large pipe and wears face paint. rdf:Description.dc:title: Sih-Chida and Mahchsi-Karehde, Mandan Indians
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Bodmer, Karl, 1809-1893
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mandan Indians; Clothing and dress; Quillwork; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Tableau 20 in atlas: Illustrations to Maximilian, Prince of Wied's Travels in the interior of North America. Portrait of Sih-Chida, "Yellow Feather" and Mahchsi-karehde, "Flying War Eagle". Sih-Chida, on the left, wears beaded hairbows with long strings of dentalium shells and beads. He wears a buffalo hide robe with large quilled rosettes, and an otter fur with fringed leather around his neck. His red "heal trailers" signify battle exploits and are made of otto fur lined with red cloth. Mahchsi-karehde, a member of the Soldier Society wears a painted robe with quilled rosettes, leggings and moccasins. He wears large shell or metal disc earrings and wolf tails on his heals which signify success in war. Both men wear hearbows and feather headdresses. Mahchsi-karehde wears a bearclaw necklace and carries an eagle-wing fan both which signify wealth and status. In 1836 Maximilian commissioned Bodmer to create illustrations to accompany the text of his atlas documenting their travels. These illustrations include 81 plates of aquatints.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 drawing; 55.5 x 44 cm Aquatints; Portraits; Works of art Tiff
rdf:Description.dc:source: London: Ackermann and Co. rdf:Description.dc:title: Hawgone
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Burbank, E. A. (Elbridge Ayer), 1858-1949
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Silver Horn, 1860-1940; Kiowa Indians; Kings and rulers; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Portrait of Hawgone (Silver Horn), a warrior and artist of the Kiowa Indian Tribe of Okalahoma. Frontal view from the waist up. Pictured wrapped in a red cloth with only the head visible. Wears a headdress with feathers, fur, and horns. "HAWGONE." written in brown paint on upper left corner. Signed "E.A. BURBANK. FT. SILL. O.T." in brown paint in lower right corner. Unframed oil painting on canvas. Burbank, travelling through the American West for two decades, painted and drew individuals from more than 125 tribes.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 painting; 33 x 51 cm Oil paintings; Portraits; Works of art Tiff

rdf:Description.dc:title: Indian Utensils and arms
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Bodmer, Karl, 1809-1893
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Implements, utensils, etc.; Indian weapons; Weapons
rdf:Description.dc:description: Tableau 48 in atlas: Illustrations to Maximilian, Prince of Wied's Travels in the interior of North America. Variety of objects collected by Prince Maximillian, from the Plains Indian tribal communities. Objects include Sioux and Iroquois moccasins, quill-decorated otter skin, bows, an eagle-feather war bonnet, a double-goose-bone war whistle, a hair roach, a Sioux pipe, painted rawhide storage bag, a Mandan hoop-and-pole game item, a lance, a pipe temper, ceremonial drum, pipe with eagle feathers, cloth, horsehair and woodpecker bills, a stone knife and an elaborate warshield, and medicine bundles. With a Karl Bodmer stamp of ownership. In 1836 Maximilian commissioned Bodmer to create illustrations to accompany the text of his atlas documenting their travels. These illustrations include 81 plates of aquatints.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Abdih-Hiddisch. A Minatarre Chief
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Bodmer, Karl, 1809-1893
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Hidatsa Indians; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Medals; Tattooing; Indians of North America Peace medals
rdf:Description.dc:description: Tableau 24 in atlas: Illustrations to Maximilian, Prince of Wied's Travels in the interior of North America. Portrait of Abdih-Hiddisch, "Road-Maker", a Minatari or Hidatsa Chief who was a keeper of the tribal medicine bundle and had an extensive military record. He is adorned with tattoos on his chest, right arm and hand, neck and face. He wears a European hat with a coup feather, a peace medal around his neck, leggings with beaded strips and painted loops, and bird designs on his moccasins. He holds a war axe or hatchet in his right hand. In 1836 Maximilian commissioned Bodmer to create illustrations to accompany the text of his atlas documenting their travels. These illustrations include 81 plates of aquatints.

rdf:Description.dc:description: Tableau 23 in atlas: Illustrations to Maximilian, Prince of Wied's Travels in the interior of North America. Portrait of Pehriska-Ruhpa, "Two Ravens", principal leader of the Hidatsa Dog Society performing a traditional dance in full costume. His blue headdress is made of magpie and wild turkey feathers. He wears a long cloth mantle over his shoulder, a war whistle and holds a society emblem, of a rattle made of deer hooves or deer claws attached to a beaded stick in his right hand and a bow and arrows in his left hand. In 1836 Maximilian commissioned Bodmer to create illustrations to accompany the text of his atlas documenting their travels. These illustrations include 81 plates of aquatints.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Pahl-Lee, Moqui
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Burbank, E. A. (Elbridge Ayer), 1858-1949
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Hopi Indians; Hopi women; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Portrait of Pahl-Lee, a Hopi Indian woman. Right profile from the waist up. Pictured wrapped in a brown, red and white cloth, with hair forming a whorl, and adorned with earring, necklace and bracelets. "PAHL-LEE. MOQUI." written in red paint on upper left corner. Signed "E.A. BURBANK. KEAMS CANYON. 1898. ARIZ." in gray paint in lower left corner. Framed oil painting on wood. Burbank, travelling through the American West for two decades, painted and drew individuals from more than 125 tribes.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Erouk, a native of Prince Regent's Bay
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Inuit; Clothing and dress; Dogs; Dogsledding; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 1. Inuit man stands in fur suit with hood, mittens, and boots. His companion sits in sled, with sled dogs to the left. Both men hold spears resembling narwhal tusks. Image labelled ""Lat. 76 12 N Long. 65 W. -"" Prince Regent's Inlet is located in what is now Nunavut, Canada.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Eskimaux of the Clyde, west coast of Baffin's Bay
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Inuit; Inuit women; Inuit children; Clothing and dress; Explorers; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 2. Inuit woman with facial tattoos stands with child on her back. A bearded European man sits on a rock. They wear sealskin shirts, pants, and boots.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kisharrah, a Copper Indian guide, and daughter, Green Stockings
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Copper Inuit; Clothing and dress; Indian women; Snowshoes and snowshoeing; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 3. A man stands in a fur, facing a woman sitting on the ground. She mends a snowshoe. From ""Journey to the shores of the polar seas in the years 1819, 20, 21 and 22,"" by John Franklin; p. 254, ""Keskarrah and his daughter,"" by Lt. Robert Hood.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Natives of Nootka Sound
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Fences; Canoes and canoeing
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 4. Three people in foreground, wearing white shawls and wraps around their legs. One person sits in a canoe in the water, holding a stick; one stands with stick on shore; one faces away. Two others in background crouch in front of wooden building amid pine trees. A wooden fence (grid made of poles) stands on shore.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Natives of Norton's Sound, N.W. coast of America
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Indian women; Clothing and dress; Dwellings
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 5. Woman, holding pail and child on her back, stands with bearded man, holding fish. They wear shirts, leggings, and shoes with curled soles. Wooden lodge, kayak, and pile of fish in background. Labelled ""Lat 64 o55 North Long 102 o13 East."" Similar to ""Inhabitants of Norton Sound and their habitations,"" John Webber, 1778.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Chief of the Pal-lo-to-path or Flathead Indians
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Salish Indians; Kings and rulers; Clothing and dress; Indian women; Indian children; Fishing; Manners and customs Spears; Trees
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 6. Man stands with spear, fringed leggings, belt of white tails, mallet or shaker, necklace of claws, and septum piercing. Woman stands next to him with fishing pole or spear, basket of fish, checkered skirt, and moccasins. The baby on her back has horizontal board on its head for ""flattening"" (thus the ""Flatheads""--however, this tribe never really engaged in this practice). They stand near a creek amid pine trees.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Eskimaux of Point Barrow, Arctic Sea
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Inuit; Clothing and dress; Indians of North America Dogs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 7. Portrait of three men in hooded fur suits. Two have pelts attached to their belts. One pets a dog. One sits on a railing or fence.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Stephan of the Chiche Nation, residing n. west of the Columbia River
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Indian women; Indian children; Mountains
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 8. Man with fringed shirt and decorated moccasins holds bow and arrows. Wears a knife in a sheath around his neck. Second man sits on ground, holding shield and wearing hat with horns or wings. He plays a flute or smokes a pipe. A woman stands holding a baby and wearing a straw woven hat. A spear and a paddle lay on the ground. Pine trees, mountains, and river in background. Note on lower left: ""Chichilek,"" possibly meaning ""Chiheeleesh,"" a tribe 40 miles north of the Columbia.
rdf:Description.dc:coverage: United States--Lower Columbia River; United States--Columbia River Valley

rdf:Description.dc:title: Dance of the N.W. Indians, at the Mission of St. Jose de California
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Ohlone Indians; Dance; Clothing and dress; Mission San Jose (Alameda County, Calif.); Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 9. Four men with elaborate body paint dancing. One man twirls small sticks between his fingers and wears a white hat with a protruding leafy twig. One man wears a turban-like hat. Mission San Jose was built near the Ohlone village of Oroysom.

rdf:Description.dc:title: San Jose de California, Nueva
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Ohlone Indians; Clothing and dress; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 10. Two men standing with elaborate body paint and feathered headbands.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Big bug dress of an Indian magician
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Sihasapa Indians; Shamans; Rites and ceremonies; Clothing and dress; Indians of North America; Drum; Spears
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 11. Caption: ""Performing the ceremony of medicine man over an Indian Blackfoot chief."" Rendering of Catlin's ""Blackfoot Medicine Man."" Man stands holding spear and tambourine-like drum. He wears a full wolf or bear skin, including the head. Copious fringe on the skin falls from the man's arms and legs, obscuring all but his hands and feet. In the fringe are stuffed animal skins, including a duck, snakes, small rodents, fox, and frog.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Shoshone Chief in full dress, Stony Mountain Indian
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Shoshoni Indians; Kings and rulers; Clothing and dress; Indians of North America; Mountains
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 12. Man stands under a tree, addressing a crowd of men with shaved heads. He wears a leather tunic. He is either wearing a hood or has curly red hair. A man in the crowd wears a hat with two horns.

rdf:Description.dc:title: North American Indian performing Buffalo Bull Dance
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Indian dance
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 13. A North American Indian man in traditional dress with headdress and dance rattle performing the Buffalo Bull Dance.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mandan Indians -- The Evil Spirit arrested in his progress, Ka-se-pah
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mandan Indians; Rites and ceremonies; Indians of North America; Bears
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 14. Caption: ""Okee-hee-de, the Evil Spirit, the diluvian destroyer about to be arrested in his progress by the Ka-se-pah with the medicine pipe and repelled from the big canoe or ark."" Rendering of the Mandan flood ceremony. Man painted black (with white spots) runs with a long red-tipped stick. He passes three bears guarding a tall wooden structure (the ""ark"" or ""big canoe""), and man with a pipe, and another man sitting with a mallet or shaker.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Sewessissing, a brave of the Eowagh or Iowa tribe of Indians
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Iowa Indians; Clothing and dress; Dwellings; Tipis; Indians of North America Dogs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 16. A man sits on a rock outside a tipi with a dog. His head is shaved into a partial mohawk. He has one feather in his hair, a medal around his neck, earring, body paint, a blue breech cloth, a dagger, and a long pipe. A second man heads toward the tipi with a long rifle. Additional signature at lower left (Johnathan Amherstburgh?).

rdf:Description.dc:title: Sewessissing, chief of the Eowahs, N. America, Sioux nation
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Iowa Indians; Kings and rulers; Indian women; Clothing and dress; Indians of North America Waterfalls
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 16. Man and woman in forest scene. He sits on a rock with a long, twisted pipe, blue breech cloth, and dagger in his belt. He holds an ax or tomahawk in his right hand, earrings, and body paint. His hair is mostly shaved except the crown, where there are feathers. The woman wears a blue skirt, necklace, and fur shawl. She holds a small pelt to the Iowa chief. Caption: ""From Life Canada. American Type.""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ottoe or Ottowa Chief
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Oto Indians; Spears Feathers
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 17. Two men facing each other. One wears medal on necklace and white breech cloth, holding spear. The chief has elaborate body paint (or tattoos), leggings, black sash, and holds a pipe. Both men have shaved heads, except hair and feathers at crown of head. The caption could refer to either the Oto or Ottawa Indians.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kis-ov-san-ches -- the Spaniard, a half-breed Comanche chief with a buffalo skin flag of truce
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Comanche Indians; Kings and rulers; Clothing and dress; Indians of North America; Horses Spears; Rifles
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 18. Man on rearing white horse holds a long spear with a furry white flag, shield, three red feathers in his hair, and leggings with red and white fringe. His rifle is also decorated. Trail of Indians on horseback in background.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Two warriors and a woman of the Sacs and Foxes mourning over the tomb of Black Hawk
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Indiand women; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Sauk Indians; Kings and rulers; Black Hawk, Sauk chief, 1767-1838
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 19. Two men and woman (Sauk and Fox Indians) on mound. She wears a white dress. One man holds shield and spear decorated with feathers, armbands and quiver. Both men wear feathered headdresses. A spear with bow, quiver, and feathered shield stands on the mound, and two sashes and a tomahawk rest on the ground.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Crow Indian
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Crow Indians; Clothing and dress; Indians of North America; Horses; Spears Feathers
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 20. From Catlin, Plate 76. Rear view of man riding horse. He wears a feathered headdress, a shield, and multicolored fringe on his tunic and leggings. He holds a long spear. His horse also has a feathered headdress and a decorated saddle blanket.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Pawnee Indians, mounted and painted for battle
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Pawnee Indians; Indians of North America; Horses; Spears; Shields Feathers
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 21. Man on horseback wears split horn head band and shield. He and his horse are decorated with feathers and red face paint. Horse has striped saddle blanket.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Indian painted buffalo skin
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Pawnee Indians; Battles; Combat; Horses; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 22. Sketch of buffalo skin featuring approximately twenty men on horses with shields and spears, advancing toward men on foot or lying on ground. Caption: ""Representing an attack of the Pawnees upon the [Housa or Kiowa] Nation.""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Sa-Ga-Yeath-Qua-Pieth-Tow, chief of the Maquas
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mohawk Indians; Kings and rulers; Clothing and dress; Indians of North America; Rifles; Bears Tribal chiefs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 23. Mohawk civil chief with chest tattoos, red cloak, and white tunic stands in front of a tree holding a musket. He wears downy white feathers over each ear, sash with powderhorn, ax, decorated belt and moccasins with red ribbons. A bear lies at his feet, bleeding from the mouth. Rendering of Jan Verelst's oil painting commissioned for the meeting of four chiefs of the Iroquois Confederacy with Queen Anne in London, 1710. Sa Ga Yeath Qua Peith Tow's Christian name was Peter Brant.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Iroquois or Mohawk chief
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Kings and rulers Feathers
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 24. Sketch with sepia-colored watercolor. Man stands holding war club, with feathered head band, necklace, and moccasins. There is a bird design on his shirt, and he holds what appears to be a book under his arm.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Iroquois or Algonquin, about 1790
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Indian women Feathers
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 25. Man and woman standing. Woman wears necklace, red leggings, and leather dress. Man wears cape, breech cloth, necklace, feathers on his shaved head, and body paint or tattoos on his chest and head. He also carries a quiver with arrows, ax or tomahawk, dagger, and long stick.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Virginia, 1590
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Indian women; Bow and arrow Feathers
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 26. Man and woman. Both wear fringed skirts or breech cloths and elaborate hair decorations. He wears large earrings and holds an arrow and a long stick.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Secolinsian sachem and young mother, Virginia, 1580
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Indian women; Clothing and dress; Kings and rulers; Indian children; Owls Tribal chiefs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 27. Sachem (civil chief) stands with long fur shawl and an owl on his shoulder. He wears a long pleated tunic and his hair is partially shaved. He holds a shield or drum with feathers. A woman with a child on her back stands near.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Cholovonis of Bay San Francisco, California
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Yokuts Indians; Hunting; Indians of North America; Bow and arrow
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 29. Two Cholbones (or Chulamni) men standing on hill, with bows, arrows, and animal skin quivers. They wear no clothing but have yellow hair decorations and stretched earlobes with bone decorations. The Cholbones were Northern Valley Yokuts. Based on Louis Choris, Voyage autour du Monde by Louis Choris, Plate XIII (1816).

rdf:Description.dc:title: Harriet Huronne & another female of Lorette Sauvage Harriet Huronne and another female of Lorette Sauvage
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Wyandot Indians; Indian women; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 30. Harriet and another Huron, or Wyandot, Indian woman of the village of Lorette Sauvage in Qu?bec standing in traditional dress.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mesteese and mulatto girls of Dominica
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of the West Indies; Indian women; Clothing and dress; Rivers
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 31. Two women at creek. One holds a wooden paddle; the other carries a large wooden board. A bundle of cloth lies on a rock in the creek. Both women have their hair wrapped in fabric.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Red Caribs
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Cariban Indians; Clothing and dress; Indian women; Indian children; Breastfeeding; Indians of the West Indies Bow and arrow
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 32. Man and woman with child outside dwelling. Woman wears necklace, breech cloth, and red bands at arms, knees, and ankles. She is breastfeeding a baby. Man wears red band in hair, at arms and knees and holds a bow.

rdf:Description.dc:title: West India Negroe women
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of the West Indies; Indian women; Indian children; Infants; Manners and customs; Dwellings; Laundry
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 33. Three women washing clothes at creek. One holds a wooden paddle and beats cloth against a rock. They wear skirts and hair wraps. One woman with a large bundle on her head has a baby tied to her back. House with porch on hill in background.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Guiana Indians
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Guayana Indians; Clothing and dress; Spears; Bow and arrow
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 34. Two men standing with spears, bows, and carved oar. They wear feathered headdresses, face paint, and sandals. One holds a drum.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Indians about Carthagena soon after the conquest of South America
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Clothing and dress; Indian women; Bow and arrow
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 35. Woman sitting on rock with pearl necklace and round objects in lap, perhaps eggs or giant pearls. Man standing with a boar-like animal holds bows and arrow. Ocean in background. Watermark: ""J Whatman, Turkey Mill, 1846.""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Cacique of Abipona Indians
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Abipon Indians; Kings and rulers; Clothing and dress; Horses; Spears; Indians of South America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 36. Cacique (tribal chief) in leopard (or ocelot) skin breech cloth rides horse with fur saddle blanket. He holds a decorated spear. Second man on horseback behind him. Abipon Indians lived primarily in Gran Chaco (part of Bolivia, Argentina, and Paraguay).

rdf:Description.dc:title: Corrienana warrior Indian and a young woman of the same tribe
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Clothing and dress; Indian women; Bow and arrow; Birds
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 37. Man with breech cloth and feather headband crouching on rock. He holds bows and arrow. Woman with white dress leaning against boulder, holding a green bird. Perhaps near Corrientes, Argentina.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mexican warrior
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of Mexico; Clothing and dress; Dwellings; Shields; Spears
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 38. Man holds shield with geometric pattern, and aims dart-shaped spear. He has red face paint and a white object wrapped in his hair. Three people (one with golden net tunic) and dwelling in background.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Two combatants of a Mexican tribe disputing the possession of a verdant field for fishing and hunting on
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of Mexico; Combat; Clothing and dress; Indian weapons; Weapons; Shields; Lances
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 39. Two men engaged in combat. Both hold shields, clubs and banner lances and wear green tunics with red designs. They wear sandals and white decorations over their ears. Two other men in combat in background. Below image, four pictographs.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mexican hunter with his squaw
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of Mexico; Clothing and dress; Indian women; Hunting; Shields; Bow and arrow
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 40. Man and woman stand holding shields with heart-shaped designs. Woman holds bow and arrow, wears brown skirt, bundle tied to her back. Man holds long spears with jagged tips, wears green knee-high leggings and gloves, bundle tied to back. His septum is pierced with a green rod. Dwelling, cactus, and mountains in background.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mexican chief, messenger or herald and a soldier
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of Mexico; Clothing and dress; Kings and rulers; Indian weapons; Weapons; Shields Tribal chiefs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 41. Three men brandishing weapons stand in front of pyramid or mound. Chief wears blue tunic, headdress and staff with fronds or green feathers, shield with flag, and club with hook. At left, man with spear and club with palm leaf-shaped end. At right, man with club, cape, and staff.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mexican chief of ocelot order in civil and military dress and a private warrior
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of Mexico; Kings and rulers; Clothing and dress; Spears; Shields
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 42. Three men in various dress. At left, man wears cape with geometric pattern and green head decoration. At center, man wears full ocelot skin, with leggings, sleeves and head, and green head decoration. He holds spear and blue shield with three white stripes and four quarter moon shapes. At right, man in blue tunic holds spear and shield made of woven grass.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mexican chief and mace bearer
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of Mexico; Clothing and dress; Kings and rulers; Manners and customs; Indian weapons; Weapons; Shields
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 43. Two men with brightly colored tunics and helmets, carrying mace and shield. Others with shields in background.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mexican Indian[s] going to market
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of Mexico; Clothing and dress; Older Indians; Indian women
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 44. Older man and woman walking along path. Man has wooden crate tied to his back and wears a straw hat, sandals, and a striped tunic. Woman has bundle on back, wears tunic, belt, skirt and hat.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mexican Indians in the holiday dress
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of Mexico; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Indian women
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 45. Man and woman in holiday regalia. Man red pants with lace, cape with ermine-like lining, striped tunic. Woman wears sheer white dress with lace over white shirt and brown skirt, and gold necklace.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mexican Indian and one of the civilized Indians
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of Mexico; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 46. Two men standing, both with straw hats. One wears furry or feathery cape. The other wears a blanket cape and black leggings. Watermark: ""J Whatman, Turkey Mill, 1850.""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mexican Indian family travelling
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of Mexico; Indian families; Families; Indian children; Indian women; Travel; Bow and arrow; Baskets
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 47. Man, woman and two children. Man carries basket on his back with a quiver of arrows, wearing hooded tunic. Child has walking stick and striped tunic. Woman wears striped hooded tunic and dress with floral design, and a baby on her back in a basket.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mexican Indians returning from market
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of Mexico; Clothing and dress; Indian women; Indian children; Infants; Guitar
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 48. Man wearing one-piece suit and black hat plays a four-string guitar (like a Venezuelan quatro). Woman with striped shawl and blue skirt holds a pot and has a baby on her back.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mexican gentleman
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mexicans; Horsemen and horsewomen; Horsemanship; Horses; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 49. Man on horseback in elaborate costume, including hat with braid, jacket and pants with silver, spurs, and long curved sword. Horse has silver bridle.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Montesuma, a Tsapotican Indian and a suppliant or priestess Montezuma, a Zapotec Indian and a suppliant or priestess
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Montezuma II, Emperor of Mexico, approximately 1480-1520; Zapotec Indians; Kings and rulers; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Indian women
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 50. Montezuma, with robe, staff, and green hair decoration, regards kneeling man with blue plumed helmet. Behind Montezuma is a woman in a blanket.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Archer of Montezuma's guard and common warrior
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of Mexico; Clothing and dress; Bow and arrow; Archery; Shields
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 51. Archer aiming bow and arrow, with ocelot or leopard skin shirt, shield strapped to forearm, red belt, and red and black face paint. Warrior holds spear and wears leather cape.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tlascaltecan chief and his apprentice warrior
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Tlaxcalan Indians; Kings and rulers; Clothing and dress; Indian weapons; Weapons; Shields Tribal chiefs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 52. Chief wears ocelot (or leopard) skin suit, headband with multicolored feathers, holds ax or tomahawk with feathers and a blue shield with white crescent shapes. Apprentice holds shield and club and carries a large (stone?) object on his back. Mountains and cactus in background.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Warriors of Mexican nation
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of Mexico; Combat; Clothing and dress; Spears Helmets
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 53. Three men standing with spears, maces, clubs, and shields. One wears a helmet and two wear ocelot (or leopard) skin suits.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Duel on the Champion Stone
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of Mexico; Combat; Clothing and dress; Indian weapons; Weapons; Shields
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 54. Two men fighting at a large stone disk with carved images (perhaps Stone of Tizoc). One man, in white cone-shaped hat and feathered pants, stands on the disk aiming a club. He holds a red object with green leaves or feathers. The second man, standing on the ground, wears an ocelot (or leopard) skin suit, including the head, and a shield. He aims a club at the other man. Note below image: ""Vol IV p 55.""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Divinity, priest or hero of Maya nation
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mayas; Kings and rulers; Clothing and dress; Rites and ceremonies
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 55. Original title: ""Divinity, priest or hero of Maya nation (the exuberant ornaments being omitted) and a figure on the doorway of the Akatziel in the same place still colored red, blue and yellow. Taken from one of the tombs of the [teocalli] at Chichen Itza."" Man holding shield in elaborate dress gestures to man sitting on stone. Standing man has arm decoration with disc at wrist. Both wear feathered headdresses.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Goddess Teoyaomqui and porphyry sacrificial stone
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Aztecs; Religion ; Rites and ceremonies; Coatlicue (Aztec deity)
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 57. Original title: ""Goddess Teoyamiqui and porphyry sacrificial stone found under the earth of the present City of Mexico. The stone is of porphyry 46 ft in circumference."" Stone statue of Aztec god of dead warriors, Teoyaomqui, decorated with skull, hearts, and hands. However, statue strongly resembles Coatlicue. People gather around flat, round stone (perhaps the Stone of Tizoc) in front of statue with flowers and incense. Note below image: ""From Bullocks Museum."" Similar to front plate in exhibition catalog for Bullock's Museum, London, ""Description of ancient Mexico collected on the spot in 1823,"" William Bullock, 1824.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Priestess? and mother and daughter
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of Mexico; Rites and ceremonies; Indian women
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 56. Person in white robe, green sash, and hat holds up a white object and gestures to two women. One woman squats on a cushion while the other touches her head.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Diluvian destroyer, personified by a Xalexallua serpent (boa) idol devouring a woman or organized life
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Aztecs; Religion; Rites and ceremonies; Snakes; Idols and images
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 58. Large statue of coiled green snake with person in mouth. People gather in front of statue. Similar to front plate in exhibition catalog for Bullock's Museum, London, ""Description of ancient Mexico collected on the spot in 1823,"" William Bullock, 1824.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Aztecan priestesses and a lady
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Aztecs; Religion; Rites and ceremonies; Aztec women; Clothing and dress; Idols and images
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 59. Rest of caption: ""Diluvian serpent painted on the wall."" Two women stand, one kneels in front of figure painting on wall. Two women wear similar white robes and headdresses; the other wears a dress of red, yellow and green.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mexi or Huitzilipritzli wearing the Curucui helmet
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Huitzilihuitl, Emperor of Mexico, -approximately 1417; Aztecs; Kings and rulers; Clothing and dress; Shields
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 60. Huitzilihuitl or Mexi sits on throne with shield, staff and cape. On his head is a yellow and white bird. Two attendants stand near with fans and staffs.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Monuments of New Spain
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Fortification; Stone walls
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 61. Brick wall encircling a hilltop, as though once a town or fortress. Below image: ""From Dupaix.""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Monuments of New Spain
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mountains
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 62. Large bricks create a doorway under a hill. Two people sit near door.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Calendar stone
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Aztec calendar; Aztec art
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 63. Drawing of circular Aztec calendar stone.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mexican temple from early Spanish print
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Temples
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 64. Original title: ""Mexican temple from an early Spanish print, and from models of pyramids and views of Mexico."" View of pyramid, platforms and walled area near water.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Montezuma proceeding in state to the temple
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Montezuma II, Emperor of Mexico, approximately 1480-1520; Indians of Mexico; Kings and rulers; Rites and ceremonies
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 65. Montezuma being carried on a covered platform by four men, with procession. Mountains and water in background. Below image: ""From two ancient prints of Mexican pictures.""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Hernan Cortez
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Cort?s, Hern?n, 1485-1547; Indians of Mexico; First contact of aboriginal peoples with Westerners; Horses Flags; Swords
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 66. Cortez, on elaborately decorated horse, holds a sword, shield, and staff with flag. He wears a red and blue suit and spurs. A man in a breech clout and sandals offers necklace. ""Ancient prints of Mexican pictures""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Hernan Cortez
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Cort?s, Hern?n, 1485-1547; Indians of Mexico; First contact of aboriginal peoples with Westerners; Horses; Clothing and dress Flags; Shields; Swords
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 67. Hernan Cortez on horse, holding sword, shield and staff with red flag. Man with club, shield, and three staffs with green feathers stands in front of horse. ""Ancient prints of Mexican pictures""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Nunez de Guzman
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Guzmn, Nuno de, active 16th century; Flags; Horses
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 68. Guzman on horseback. He holds a staff with a red flag and wears a hat with a feather. "Ancient prints of Mexican pictures."

rdf:Description.dc:title: Alto-relievo statues of priests of Yucatan or Maia
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of Mexico; Idols and images; Statues
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 69; Black and white watercolor of three male figures leaning against a pillar. Central figure has arms crossed and wears a feathered tunic. All three wear hats or helmets with disks at the ears. ""Ancient prints of Mexican pictures.""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mexican picture writing Codex Ros
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Aztecs; Antiquities; Aztec art; Religion; Quetzalcoatl (Aztec deity; Tezcatlipoca (Aztec deity)
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 71. Composite drawing with Quetzalcoatl, "sacrificing to the demon Tezcatlipoca,"" and Tzinteotl, all from Codex Vaticanus 3738 (Codex Ros). Also "ruins of Nopat," "cruciform carvings in stone, ruins of Yucatan," and other deities. "Ancient prints of Mexican pictures."

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mexican picture writing from Vatican Ms., relating to the Spanish Conquest Codex R?os
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Aztecs; Antiquities; Aztec art; Religion; Xipe Totec (Aztec deity); Tezcatlipoca (Aztec deity)
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 70. Composite drawing with four figures and several animals from Codex Vaticanus 3738 (Codex Rios). Clockwise from upper left: Naolin, Ixcuina, Xipe Totec, and Tepellolotl (Tezcatlipoca disguised in jaguar skin).

rdf:Description.dc:title: Paintings in a room at Chichen Itza, Yucatan
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mayas; Clothing and dress; Maya women; Manners and customs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 73. Four panels of male and female figures sitting, making food, dancing, constructing buildings and sitting in a long boat. Many wear hats with long green plumes. Ancient prints of Mexican pictures

rdf:Description.dc:title: Fragments of Mexican picture writing
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Aztecs; Antiquities; Manners and customs; Aztec art; Religion
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 72. Composite with many smaller images. Several priests, warriors, houses, men dressed as skeletons.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Painted bas-relief on the wall of a building at Chichen Itza
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mayas; Clothing and dress; Spears; Shields
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 74. Three panels of male figures with spears, shields, and headdresses. ""Ancient prints of Mexican pictures.""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mexican details in the British Museum
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Antiquities; Pottery
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 75. Composite drawing of statues, pottery and figurines from Mexico, Yucatan, Peru and ""New Granada."" ""Ancient prints of Mexican pictures.""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Throne and dais of Motecucuma where he sat in audience and to judge (Mendoza) Codex Mendoza
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Montezuma II, Emperor of Mexico, approximately 1480-1520; Aztecs; Kings and rulers; Buildings; Manners and customs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 76. White building with large windows, ""Palace of Motecucuma II at Tenochtitl?n."" On second floor, Montezuma sits on throne in blue robe and crown. In lower window, four judges in white sit at table. Five litigants sit outside amid footprints. Note on verso: ""Mendoza Codex, Vol III, 1938, leaf 69"" (ed. James Cooper Clark).

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tlacocalcatl or the chief of spearmen Codex Mendoza
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of Mexico; Kings and rulers; Clothing and dress; Shields; Spears
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 77. Rest of caption: ""First of the great commanders and a prince of the Inca blood of Mexico in white armor and civil costume and a priest of the Eagle order who had captured five antagonists."" Three figures in brightly colored regalia. At left, man in black body paint, red cape and green feathered headdress. At center, Tlacocalcatl with spear and shield, animal head helmet and staff with green feathers. At right, person in pink with shield and feathered staff. Below image: ""From Mendoza MS.""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Warriors, spears and shields Codex Mendoza
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Aztecs; Clothing and dress; Shields; Spears
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 78. Three warriors stand with shields and spears. Each holds a decorated staff with green feathers. Below image: ""from Mendoza M.S."" Verso: ""Mendoza vol III, 1938, leaf 67.""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Small figures from Mendoza Codex Mendoza
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Aztecs; Clothing and dress; Shields
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 79. Composite drawing of animal skin suits, shields, and headdresses. Note on verso: ""Mendoza Codex vol III 1938. Fig 1-5, leaf 19; fig 6-7, leaf 22; fig 8, leaf 20 verso"" (ed. James Cooper Clark).
rdf:Description.dc:format: Watercolors; Drawings; Portraits

rdf:Description.dc:title: Small figures from Mendoza Codex Mendoza; Shields
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Aztecs; Clothing and dress; Shields
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 80. Composite drawing of animal skin suits with helmets, shields and arrows, a staff and a green bird. From verso: ""Mendoza Codex vol III 1938."" Fig 1, 2, 4, 6, and 11 from leaf 20; fig 3, 5, and 10 from leaf 25; fig 14 from leaf 50; fig 15 from leaf 46"" (ed. James Cooper Clark).

rdf:Description.dc:title: Small figures from Mendoza Codex Mendoza
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Aztecs; Clothing and dress; Shields; Swords
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 81. Composite drawing of suits, headdresses, lances, and shields. At bottom, ""Aztecan sword or Macua-huitlze"" and ""Toltecan flint sword."" Note on verso: ""Mendoza Codex vol III 1938. Fig 1, leaf 43; Fig 2, leaf 20 verso""(ed. James Cooper Clark).

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito with basket
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Panzaleo Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 1. Quito man walking with large, wooden, cylindrical object. Object is carried by a strap. Wearing a gray shirt and knee-length shorts.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito playing music
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Musical instruments; Drum; Panzaleo Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 2. Quito man playing a drum and a woodwind instrument. Drum is decorated with red ornamentation, possibly paint. Man is wearing short pants below the knees, a poncho with brown stripes and a hat.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito woman carrying large baskets
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Indian baskets; Panzaleo Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 3. Quito woman wearing a blue dress with a belt. Carrying a large cylindrical basket attached to her by a strap around her head. She is also carrying baskets in her hands.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito walking with large pots
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Pottery; Panzaleo Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 4. Quito woman walking carrying large pottery items attached to her by straps. Carrying two smaller pots in her hands. She wears a yellow shawl over a striped dress.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito with large green baskets
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Indian baskets; Panzaleo Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 5. Profile of a Quito man walking with two staffs, carrying a large green basket with a leather strap.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito dancing with spear
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Staffs (Sticks, canes, etc.); Panzaleo Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 6. Quito dancing in elaborate dress, holding a spear. Wearing a large colorful hat.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito standing with wooden pole
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Panzaleo Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 8. Quito man standing holding a tall, wooden pole and holding a small triangle with a bell inside. Wearing a hat, a poncho and blue pants.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito riding a donkey
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Donkeys; Panzaleo Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 9. Quito woman riding a donkey, wearing a yellow shawl and a blue dress. Her hair is in a braid and she is wearing long earrings.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito in long dress
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Indian women; Panzaleo Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 10. Portrait of a Quito woman in a long, gray dress. Wearing a long, pink shawl with lace embellishment.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito carrying two small pots
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Pottery; Panzaleo Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 11. Quito man holding two pots, wearing a hat, a white scarf with red stripes, short pants and a cape.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito walking with large green basket
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Indian baskets; Body painting; Panzaleo Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 12. Quito man walking with staffs, carrying a green basket with a strap, wearing red body paint on face, arms and legs. Portrait from the front.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito with weapon
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Panzaleo Indians; Indians of South America; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Indian weapons
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 13 Quito man in profile holding a bloody weapon. Wearing a white cotton garment and a hat.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito carrying large basket of food
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Indian baskets; Panzaleo Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 14. Quito man in profile carrying a large bowl of breaded items on his head. Wearing blue trousers, a white blouse, a white poncho with red stripes.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito riding a donkey and playing an instrument
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Musical Instruments; Horses; Panzaleo Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 15. Quito man riding a horse and playing a long, wooden instrument. Wearing a shawl with stripes, hair pants, green shoes and a hat. Appears to be carrying a rug or matt.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito standing with staff
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Staffs (Sticks, canes, etc.); Panzaleo Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 16. Quito person walking with a staff, carrying two cylindrical objects. Wearing a long blouse, shorts and a striped headscarf.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito dancing in costume
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Rites and ceremonies; Panzaleo Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 17. Quito person in elaborate festival dress. Holding a curved spear in the air.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito carrying vegetables
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Panzaleo Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 18. Quito person carrying a large bundle of vegetation on back. Wearing a stripped skirt and shawl. Appears to be giving or selling food and drink.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito riding a bull
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Bulls; Panzaleo Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 19. Quito man riding a bull. Wearing long pants, shirt and head scarf.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito giving food
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Indian women; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 20. Quito woman giving a plate of food. Wearing jewelry, a full red skirt, and a green shawl over a blue shirt.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito riding horse
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Horses; Panzaleo Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 21. Quito man riding a horse and carrying a large bundle. Wearing long red jacket, green hat, a large blue striped scarf and also boots.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito in a cloak
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Panzaleo Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 22. Portrait of a Quito man standing and holding a gold object in his right hand. Wearing a long plaid cloak, a blue doublet, trousers boots and an orange hat.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito walking with a pot
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Clothing and dress; Indian pottery; Panzaleo Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 23. Quito man carrying a large pottery vessel on his back, attached with a strap. Wearing short white pants, a striped shawl. Carrying a small bowl in his left hand.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito carrying a tub
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Panzaleo Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 24. Quito man carrying a heavy tub on back, carried by a strap. Wearing short calf-length white pants, a white hat and a large striped shawl.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito in a poncho and bowtie
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Panzaleo Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 25. Portrait of a Quito man. Wearing a white poncho with large red stripes, blue stripped pants, boots and a white shirt with a red bowtie. Wearing a white hat.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito with a large spear
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Dance; Rites and ceremonies; Panzaleo Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 26. Quito man wearing ceremonial or festival dress and dancing with a long spear. Wearing red striped knickers, a necklace made of shells, and feathered head and neck ornamentation.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito in a purple dress
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Indian women; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Body painting; Panzaleo Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 27. Quito woman standing facing artist wearing a purple dress, red belt, a shawl, blue necklace and red face paint.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito in a blue dress with face paint
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Indian women; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Body painting; Panzaleo Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 28. Quito woman standing with arms folded. Wearing a purple dress with open sleeves, red necklace and blue headband. Wearing red paint in double slashes on legs, arms and face.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito holding large bundle
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Panzaleo Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 31. Quito man wearing a red striped poncho, blue trousers, a white blouse and a blue hat. Holding a tall bundle.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito with spear
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Panzaleo Indians; Indian weapons
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 32. Quito standing holding a long, metal spear. Dressed in a loose-fitting, white garment with red ornamentation.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito in black dress and tall hat
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Clothing and dress; Rites and ceremonies; Manners and customs; Panzaleo Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 33. Quito in elaborate festival costume. Wearing black dress with basket-shaped skirt, black shoes with buckles, white shawl and white gloves. Wearing a very tall, thin conical or capuchin hat adorned with long black ribbons. Holding a sword in left hand and a thin, object in right that is light with fire. Face is completely covered in black cloth.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito in foliage costume
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Panzaleo Indians; Rites and ceremonies
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 34. Quito portrait of individual covered in a foliage costume. Wearing a feathered headdress.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito selling fruit
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Indian women; Clothing and dress; Commerce; Manners and customs; Panzaleo Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 35. Seated Quito woman selling fruit. Wearing a full blue skirt, and a white blouse.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito in white costume with very tall hat
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Panzaleo Indians; Religion
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 36. Quito in a long, white costume with a belt. Face covered with a white cloth, wearing gloves and holding a small cloth. Wearing a tall, thin white hat with red and blue striped ornamentation. Long ribbons hang off of the end of the hat.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quito costumes
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Salas, Ramn, 1815-1880
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of South America -- Portraits; Indians of South America -- Clothing and dress; Indians of South America -- Social life and customs; Indians of South America -- Implements
rdf:Description.dc:description: Collection of 36 original watercolors by Ecuadorian artist, Ramon Salas who originated "Quito Manners and Customs." These natural watercolors depict the dress, culture and social customs of the inhabitants of Quito, Ecuador in the 19th century.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 2 boxes (36 drawings): 33 x 25 cm Watercolors; Portraits; Works of art Tiff
