rdf:Description.dc:title: Pueblo of Zuni, New Mexico
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Zuni architecture; Zuni Indians; Dwellings; Pueblos; Domestic animals; Sheep; Horses; Villages
rdf:Description.dc:description: Exterior street scene of Zuni pueblo (village). Scene shows wooden fence, dirt roads, stone or adobe dwellings with ladders, beasts of burden, sheep and people.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Interior of an estufa, New Mexico
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Pueblo Indians; Dwellings; Manners and customs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Interior of Pueblo dwelling with stone floor, support columns and wooden beams in ceiling. Several people sitting. Also shows drum, large vase, fire pit and ladder. Scene done in sepia tones.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Pueblo of Laguna, New Mexico
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Laguna Indians; Structures; Dwellings; Pueblos; Rivers; Villages
rdf:Description.dc:description: Landscape of Laguna, New Mexico. Many stone or adobe dwellings, with ladders, on top of a hill near a river. Wooden fences for animals. On rock in foreground, across the river from the village, are three people.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Herd of buffalo
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Bison
rdf:Description.dc:description: Scenic landscape with herd of buffalo and grassy plains

rdf:Description.dc:title: Hunting the buffalo in winter
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Bison; Dakota Indians; Hunting; Bow and arrow
rdf:Description.dc:description: Two Dakota Indians clad in skins and snowshoes hunting buffalo with bow, arrow and spear amid snowy landscape.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Interior of old mill, Newport, R.I.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mills; Horses
rdf:Description.dc:description: Sepia-toned watercolor of crumbling exterior brick wall with arches. Two men sit in the shadows of the ruins, with horse or donkey, fence and houses in background.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mackinac
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Canoes and canoeing; Lakes
rdf:Description.dc:description: Landscape featuring Mackinac, Michigan, with Fort Mackinac on a ridge above town. In foreground, Indians approach the shoreline in canoes.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Domestic cow and buffalo
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Bison; Cows
rdf:Description.dc:description: A white and tan cow and black buffalo stand on grassy plain, facing left. Trees, hills and sky in background.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Inscription Rock on the Allegany River below Franklin, Pa.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Fishing; Petroglyphs; Rivers Stone carvings
rdf:Description.dc:description: Outdoor scene of man fishing at the Allegheny River. He wears a wide-brimmed hat. A large rock with slanted surface and inscription sits on the bank (also known as Indian God Rock). Done in sepia tones.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Porcupine Mountains, Lake Superior
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mountains; Lakes Porcupine Mountains
rdf:Description.dc:description: Scenic landscape with rock outcroppings, trees, and deer in foreground. Behind are Lake Superior and hills.
rdf:Description.dc:coverage: Lake Superior; Michigan--Porcupine Mountains State Park

rdf:Description.dc:title: Nadowaqua
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Algonquin Indians; Indian women; Kings and rulers; Older Indians; Health
rdf:Description.dc:description: Rendering of the tale of Nadowaqua, who carried her aged father (Le Grand Sable, a chief) on her back when he was aged and too weak to walk. Here they follow a trail of other Algonquins to Lake Michigan, near Michilimackinac (now Mackinac County, Michigan).

rdf:Description.dc:title: Watercolor drawings to illustrate Henry Rowe Schoolcraft's Historical and statistical information respecting the history, condition and prospects of the Indian tribes of the United States, 1853
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Eastman, Seth, 1808-1875
rdf:Description.dc:description: Eleven watercolor drawings, ten of which were submitted in Oct., 1853, for use in Volume IV of Schoolcraft's government-sponsored study of the Indian tribes of the United States. Included are three views of Laguna and Zuni Indian life in New Mexico painted from sketches by R.H. Kern; three buffalo and buffalo hunt scenes; views of Fort Mackinac on Mackinac Island, Inscription Rock on the Alleghany River near Franklin, Pa., and the Porcupine Islands on Lake Superior (from Schoolcraft sketch); and one historical depiction entitled ""Nadowaqua."" There is also one watercolor drawing of a Newport, R.I., mill which Eastman visited in 1853; another view of this scene was also used in Vol. IV of Schoolcraft.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 box (11 drawings): watercolor; 32 x 40 cm Watercolors; Drawings; Landscapes (Representations); Works of art Tiff
rdf:Description.dc:relation: Edward E. Ayer Art Collection (Newberry Library) Edward E. Ayer Digital Collection (Newberry Library)
rdf:Description.dc:coverage: Indians in art; Indians of North America --Pictorial works

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ee-ah-sa-pa. (The Black Rock)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Dakota Indians; Clothing and dress; Indian weapons; Weapons
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 1. Portrait of Ee-ah-sa-pa, head Sioux war chief of the tribe. He is dressed in a very elaborate robe decorated with battle scenes and a large rosette. He is wearing a large head dress made of war eagle's quills, ermine fur and a pair of horns. He is holding a lance in his hand.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Wi-loo-tah-eeh-tchah-ta-ma-nee (the Red Thing that Touches the Ground When Marching)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indian women; Dakota Indians; Clothing and dress; Indians of North America; Indian beadwork
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 2. Portrait of of Wi-loo-tah-eeh-tchah-ta-ma-nee, daughter of a war chief Ee-ah-sa-pa wearing a deer skin dress and a buffalo skin robe, decorated with painted and embroidered ornamentation. Her hair is braided and she is wearing several beaded necklaces.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Wife of Ee-ah-sa-pa
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indian women; Indian children; Dakota Indians; Manners and customs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 3. Wife of Ee-ah-sa-pa carrying an infant upon her back in a basket embroidered with porcupine quills dyed of bright colors. The basket is tied to a straight, wooden board. Her hair is worn long and loose and she appears to be carrying a bow and arrow set in her right hand. Another child accompanies her.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mah-to-chee-ga (the Little Bear)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Dakota Indians; Clothing and dress; Tomahawks; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 4. Portrait of a distinguished warrior of the Sioux tribe. He is wearing a buffalo robe with painted ornamentation of war scenes. He wears feathers in his hair, beaded necklaces and earrings, face paint and is holding a pipe tomahawk.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Shon-ka (the Dog)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Dakota Indians; Clothing and dress; Calumets; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 5. Portrait of a warrior of the Sioux tribe wearing a hide shirt with scalp lock fringe, embroidery and a painted war scene. He is wearing several bead necklaces and is holding a peace pipe decorated with eagle plumes in his right hand and a shield in his left.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tah-teck-a-da-har (the Steep Wind)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Dakota Indians; Clothing and dress; Indians of North America; Indian weapons; Weapons
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 6. A Sioux warrior wearing a buffalo robe decorated with porcupine quills, fringe made of the hair of his enemies killed by him called scalp locks. He is wearing a feathered headdress, is holding a set of bow and arrows and has a large bow and quiver slung across his back.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Wan-ee-ton
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Dakota Indians; Sisseton Indians; Clothing and dress; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 7. Portrait of the Chief of the Sisseton Band of the Sioux Tribe. He is wearing a shirt and leggings, decorated with ""scalp-locks"". His full-body headdress consists of War Eagle plumes. His necklace is made of grizzly bear claws. He is also wearing a buffalo hide blanket with embroidery.

rdf:Description.dc:title: A Susseton warrior
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Dakota Indians; Sisseton Indians; Clothing and dress; Indians of North America; Indian weapons; Weapons
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 8. Portrait of a famous warrior of the Sisseton band of the Sioux Tribe. He is carrying a shield made of buffalo hide and a quiver made of panther skin, filled with arrows. He appears to be wearing a buffalo hide blanket, is wearing feathers in his hair and is holding a lance.

rdf:Description.dc:title: A Sioux girl, daughter of Wan-ee-ton
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indian children; Girls; Sisseton Indians; Clothing and dress; Dakota Indians; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 9. Portrait of a young Sioux girl, the daughter of the Chief of the Susseton Band, Wan-ee-ton. She is clothing in buffalo hide, and is wearing beaded necklaces and earrings. She has painted circles on each cheek and her forehead and her hair is worn loose.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Wa-nah-de-tunk-a (the Black Dog)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Pipes
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 10

rdf:Description.dc:title: The Red Wing Chief of a Band of Sioux on the Upper Missouri River
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Dakota Indians; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 11. Portrait of a Red Wing Chief. He is wearing a buffalo hide blanket, beaded earrings and several necklaces with a peace medal and two large feathers in his hair.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Toh-to-wa-kon-da-pee (the Blue Medicine)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Shamans; Indians of North America; Dakota Indians; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Rites and ceremonies
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 12. Portait of a medicine man wearing face paint, an elaborate beaded shirt with feathers, and beaded necklaces, one with a large medallion. He is carrying medicinal items amd is beating a medicine or mystery drum.

rdf:Description.dc:title: A Sioux woman and child
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indian women; Indian children; Indians of North America; Manners and customs; Dakota Indians; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 13. Depiction of a Sioux woman, the wife of Chief Wa-nah-de-tunk-a and her young child. She is wearing a skin dress and several beaded necklaces and appears to be breastfeeding her young child.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ha-wan-je-tah (the One Horn)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Dakota Indians; Clothing and dress; Tobacco pipes
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 14. Portrait of the head chief of the Sioux tribe in a costume decorated with procupine quill embroidery and fringed with scalp locks. He is shown seated, smoking a long pipe and a painted buffalo hide on his lap. His hair is elaborately tied and he wears jewelry.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tchon-dee (Tobacco)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Dakota Indians; Clothing and dress; Indian weapons; Weapons
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 15. Portrait of a Sioux warrior in an elaborate costume with scalp locks fringe on his hide shirt and leggings, feathered hair ornamentation, and beaded necklaces. He is holding a lance and a shield decorated with the face of a buffalo.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Toh-ki-e-to (Stone with Horns)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Dakota Indians; Clothing and dress; Tattooing; Manners and customs; Tobacco pipes
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 16. Portait of a great medicine man and counselor of the chief. He is holding a very large pipe and is wearing hide leggings with scalp locks and embroidery. He is wearing several beaded necklaces, a headdress and is body is largely covered with tattoos. At his feet is a shield, and a small bundle, probably holding medicinal items or tobacco.

rdf:Description.dc:title: A Sioux woman, youngest wife of Ha-wan-je-tah.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indian women; Indian children; Indians of North America; Manners and customs; Dakota Indians; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 17. Portrait of a young Sioux woman holding her infant in a cradle. She is wearing an embroidered blanket and several beaded necklaces. There are several feathers in her hair, which is partially braided.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Sho-me-cos-see (the Wolf)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Kansa Indians; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Tobacco pipes
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 18. Portrait of the head chief wearing a buffalo hide robe decorated with battles he had fought and closed with a large medallion. He is wearing several strands of beads and an elaborate quilled, and headdress with deer tail hair and feathers. He is smoking a very long pipe.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Wa-hon-ga-shee (No Fool)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Kansa Indians; Manners and customs; Clothing and dress; Rites and ceremonies; Tomahawks
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 19. A warrior of the Kanza tribe, is wearing war dress and paint, several strands of beads with a peace medal, a headdress with what looks like a peacock feather. He is holding a very large war club in his arms.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Chesh-oo-hong-ha (the Man of Good Sense)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Kansa Indians; Clothing and dress; Body painting; Manners and customs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 20. Portrait of a young Kanza man wearing a traditional crest made of dyed deers tail and horsehair over his shaved head. He is wearing several strands of beads, multiply earrings, body paint and is clothed in a blanket. He appears to have a tomahawk tucked into his clothing.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Meach-o-shin gaw (the Little White Bear)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Kansa Indians; Manners and customs; Indian weapons; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 21. Portrait of a noted warrior dressed and equipped for war. Wearing the traditional headdress, several strands of beads, an elaborate belt and is drawing his bow and arrow. He is wearing a very large and heavily decorated belt with a scalping knife tucked into it. He is wearing body paint and a peace medal.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mon-so-a
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indian women; Kansa Indians; Clothing and dress; Indians in art; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 21b. Portrait of a Kanza woman, wife of a warrior. She is wearing multiple beaded necklaces and a hide dress. Her hair is worn loose and parted down the middle. She is wearing three painted dots on her face and multiple earrings.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ka-bes-kunk (He Who Stinks Everywhere)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Ojibwa Indians; Manners and customs; Tomahawks; Indian weapons; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 22. Portrait of a distinguished Ojibwa warrior. He is wearing war dress and body paint and is carrying his tomahawk and tobacco pouch in his left hand and his war club and medicine bag in his right. He wears several feathers in his hair.

rdf:Description.dc:title: O-ta-wa (the Ottaway)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Ojibwa Indians; Manners and customs; Clothing and dress; Indian weapons
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 23. Portrait of a celebrated warrior clothed in full war paint and dress. He is wearing several strands of beads and bands at his wrists and elbows. He wears a large, feathered headdress and holds a lance in his hand.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ju-a-kiss-gaw
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Ojibwa Indians; Manners and customs; Clothing and dress; Indian women; Indian children; Cradleboards
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 24. Ju-a-kiss-gaw, an Ojibwa woman carrying her infant in a cradle. She appears to be wearing a hide dress with embroidery or beaded ornamentation. She carries her baby in an embroidered cradleboard. She is the wife of O-ta-wa.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Gitch-ee-gaw-ga-osh (the Paint That Remains Forever)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Ojibwa Indians; Clothing and dress; Tobacco pipes
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 25. Portrait of an Ojibwa chief. He is wearing what appears to be a blanket, two necklaces and a feather in his hair. His seated and is holding a large pipe across his lap.

rdf:Description.dc:title: On-daig (the Crow)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Ojibwa Indians; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 26. Portrait of a seated young Ojibwa man. His hair is in braids and decorated with feathers. He is wearing boots, embroidered shorts or leggings, a cloth around his waist, armbands at his elbows, several strands of beads and one with a peace medal. He is holding a large fan made of an eagle's tail in his hand.

rdf:Description.dc:title: I-an-be-wa-dick (the Male Caribou)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Ojibwa Indians; Clothing and dress; Indian weapons; Bow and arrow
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 27. Young warrior, seated on the ground, in war paint and war dress. His hair is in braids, and decorated with a feathered headdress. His leggings are fringed with scalp locks and he is holding a bow and arrow.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Sha-co-pay (the Six)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Ojibwa Indians; Clothing and dress; Indian embroidery; Quillwork
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 29. Portrait of the head chief of the Ojibwa tribe in an elaborate skin dress, decorated with embroidered quillwork, a tribal scene and an abundance of scalp locks. His hair is in two beaded braids, and adorned with many feathers and deer hair. He wears a large necklace and many earrings.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Me-nis-ka
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Ojibwa Indians; Clothing and dress; Indian women
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 30. Portrait of an Ojibwa woman, wife of Sha-co-pay. She is wearing a large buffalo skin robe, many strings of beads and earrings. Her hair is worn loose.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Naw-kaw (the Wood)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Winnebago Indians; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 31. An aged man: head chief of his tribe with his war club on his arm. A numerous and warlike tribe, now reduced to a few hundreds. Upper Mississippi and Wisconsin Rivers

rdf:Description.dc:title: Wah-chee-has-ka (He Who Puts All Out of Doors)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Winnebago Indians; Clothing and dress; Tobacco pipes; Body painting
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 32. Portrait of a Winnebago warrior. He is wearing a short shirt, leggings, body and face paint and armbands with long rattle snake skins. He is wearing several strings of beads, one with a peace medal, several earrings and several feathers in his hair. He is smoking a curved pipe and is holding a long item in his left hand.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Wa-kon-chash-kaw (He Who Comes on the Thunder)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Winnebago Indians; Clothing and dress; Indian weapons
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 33. A young warrior holding his war club. He is wearing a feathered headdress, earrings and several strands of beads. He is wearing a blanket that is closed by a large medallion or rosette.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Hoo-wa-nee-kaw (the Little Elk)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Winnebago Indians; Clothing and dress; Indian weapons
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 34. Portrait of a young Winnebago warrior wearing an embroidered robed and holding his war club in his arms. He is wearing several beaded necklaces, his hair is partially braided and he wears various types of feathers in his hair.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Wi jun-jon (the Pigeon's Egg Head)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Assiniboine Indians; Clothing and dress; Indian beadwork; Manners and customs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 35. Portrait of a distinguished Assiniboine warrior, son of the head chief of the tribe. He is wearing skin clothing, deecorated with beadwork, scalp locks and personal war scenes.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Chin-cha-pee (the Fire Bug that Creeps)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Indian women; Assiniboine Indians; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Tools
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 36. Portrait of an Assiniboine woman and the wife of Wi jun-jon. She is wearing an animal hide dress and is holding a tool said to be used for digging wild turnips. Her hair is braided and she is wearing beaded necklaces, earrings and face paint

rdf:Description.dc:title: Nee-kin-nee
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Assiniboine Indians; Clothing and dress; Indian children
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 37. Portrait of an Assiniboine girl, daughter of Wi jun-jon and Chin-cha-pee. She is wearing an embroidered dress made of mountain sheep skins. She is wearing jewelry and her hair is braided.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Teeh-toot-sa
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Kiowa Indians; Clothing and dress; Body painting; Shields
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 38. Portrait of the head chief of the Kiowa tribe. He is dressed in an animal skin robe and is wearing many strands of beads and a long strand of large discs. He is also wearing bands at his elbows and wrists and face. He holds a shield decorated with a buffalo head and his face and body are painted.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Bon son jee (New Fire)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Kiowa Indians; Clothing and dress; Indian weapons; Body painting; Weapons
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 39. Portrait of a famous Kiowa warrior in war paint and war dress. He is wearing several strands of beads, including one with a talon. He hair is loose, decorated with a single feather and an arrow. He wears bands at his wrists and is holding a war club.

rdf:Description.dc:title: A Kiowa young woman and boy
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Kiowa Indians; Clothing and dress; Indian women; Indian children
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 40. Portrait of two young Kiowa Indians, brother and sister. They are both dress in animal hide blankets and strands of beads. The young girl is wearing earrings and wrist bands.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mah-to-toh-pa (the Four Bears)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Mandan Indians; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Decoration and ornament
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 41. War chief of the Mandan Indian tribe. He is depicted wearing a very elaborate skin dress, decorated with embroidery, a quilled rosette, ermine tails, scalp locks and feathers. His elaborate headdress of War Eagle plumes reaches to the ground and is decorated with horns, denoting his status as Head War Chief of the Mandan Tribe. In his hand he holds a lance or spear heavily decorated with feathers and animal skins.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mi-nee-e-sunk-te-cah (the Mink)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Indian women; Mandan Indians; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 42. A young Mandan woman, wife of the War chief Mah-to-tah-pa. She is wearing an elaborate skin dress with rosette and beadwork. She is wearing many strands of beads, beaded earrings and wrist bands. Her hair is loose and her forehead is painted. She is holding the ""historical robe"" of her husband, decorated with his war battles.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ha-na-tuh-nu-mauhk (the Wolf)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Mandan Indians; Clothing and dress; Calumets; Indian beadwork
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 43. Head (civil) chief of the Mandan tribe in a long skin dress decorated with scalp locks, beadwork and feathers. He is wearing several beaded necklaces and a peace medal. His headdress is made of feathers and he is wearing face paint. He is holding two peace pipes (calumets).

rdf:Description.dc:title: Wife and child of chief Ha-na-tah-nu-mauhk
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Mandan Indians; Clothing and dress; Indian women; Indian children
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 44. A Mandan woman and child wearing a tunic made of skins of mountain sheep and a robe of the skin of a young buffalo. The woman has very long hair that is held together by bands. She is wearing some elements of face paint.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Seek-hee-de (the Mouse Colored Feather)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Mandan Indians; Clothing and dress; Indian weapons
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 45. Portrait of a young Mandan warrior in full war dress and weaponry. His clothing consists of a skirt with a large beaded belt, multiple strands of beads, war paint and feathers in his hair. He carries many weapons including a lance, a bow, a shield quiver, a scalping knife as well as a tobacco sack from the skin of a small animal.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Un-ka-ka Ha-hon-she-kaw (the Long Finger Nails)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Mandan Indians; Clothing and dress; Indian weapons; Manners and customs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 46. Portrait of a young Mandan warrior, drawing his bow and arrow. His very large shield is decorated with buffalo's geometric ornamentation and feathers. He is wearing a single feather in his hair as well as two arrows. His hair is extremely long, extending almost to the ground and is said to be filled at intervals with customary blue and red ochre.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mah-tah-ta-ha (He Who Rushes Through the Middle)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Mandan Indians; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Indian weapons; Bow and arrow; Shields
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 47. A Mandan warrior, fully armed for battle and is drawing his bow and arrow. He is fully clothed in war paint and war dress and is equipped with a scalping knife, a bow and shield quiver slung over his shoulder. He is wearing leggings with beaded embroidery. His hair is very long and he wears feathers in his hair.

rdf:Description.dc:title: San-ja-ka-ko-ka (the Deceiving Wolf) and two young Mandan men
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Mandan Indians; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Shields; Weapons
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 48. Portrait of three young Mandan Indians in what appears to be war dress and paint. They are all wearing skin robes, feathered headdress and have very long hair, a traditional custom of the Mandan tribe. One man carries a shied.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Stu-mick-o-suks (the Buffalo's Backfat)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Sihsapa Indians; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Tobacco pipes; Indian beadwork
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 49. Portrait of the head chief of the Blackfoot tribe. He is seated and holding a heavily decorated pipe. His clothing is made of animal skins and decorated with porcupine quill embroidery and heavily fringed with scalp locks. His hair is worn loose and he is wearing earrings.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Eeh-nis-kim (the Crystal Stone)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Sihsapa Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 50. A Blackfoot woman, wife of the chief, on the foregoing page, with a fan of the Eagle's tail in her hand.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Wun-nes-tow (the White Buffalo)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Sihsapa Indians; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Indians weapon; Weapons
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 51. Portrait of a great Blackfoot medicine man. He is holding a lance in his hand, a bow and arrow set and a shield adorned with feathers. He is wearing war paint and dress, multiple strands of beads and a skin robe. His hair is worn loose and contains several feathers.

rdf:Description.dc:title: In-ne-o-cose (the Buffalo's Child)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Sihsapa Indians; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Indian weapons; Indian beadwork
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 52. Portrait of a distiguised Blackfoot warrior. He is wearing a painted buffalo skin robe, a tunic with a beaded center rosette and scalp locks on the sleeves. His hair is adorned with braids, feathers and the full skin of a small animal. He holds a lance and a medicine bag.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mix-kee-mote-skin-na (the Iron Horn)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Sihsapa Indians; Clothing and dress; Indian weapons
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 53. Portrait of a Blackfoot warrior, wearing an ornamented beuffalo skin robe and carrying a bow and panther skin quiver set slung across his back. He is wearing multiple earrings and a feathered headdress.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ah-kay-ee-pex-en (the Woman Who Strikes Many)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Indian women; Sihsapa Indians; Clothing and dress; Indian beadwork
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 54. A young Blackfoot woman shown wearing a buffalo skin robe with embroidered decoration. She is wearing several strands of beads and earrings and several long beaded stands hang from her tunic or dress. Her hair is worn loose. She is the wife of a warrior

rdf:Description.dc:title: Peh-toh-pe-kiss (the Eagle Ribs)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Sihsapa Indians; Clothing and dress; Indian beadwork; Manners and customs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 55. Portrait of the head war chief of the Blackfoot tribe. He is depicted wearing a hide shirt with scalp locksand a beaded rosette with a buffalo hide robe. His elaborate headdress appears to consist of fur, long animal hair and two large horns with denote his status in the tribe. His robe was said to have been beautifully painted.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Peh-ho-kan
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Indian women; Indian children; Sihsapa Indians; Clothing and dress; Indian beadwork
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 56. Portrait of the wife of a Blackfoot woman and wife of Peh-toh-pe-kiss. She is shown carrying a small child on her back and is completely covered in an embroidered robe of buffalo hide.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ba-da-ah-chon-du (He Who Jumps Over Everything)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Crow Indians; Clothing and dress; Indian weapons; Headdresses; Bow and arrow; Lances
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 57. Portrait over the chief of a band of the Crow Indians. He is wearing a large buffalo skin robe with painted war scenes. His bow and quiver set is slung over his back. His tunic is decorated with scalp locks and beaded rosettes. He has a sack made from the skin of an animal slung through his belt and his headdress is made of war eagle plumes and beads. He wears some face paint and several strands of beads around his neck and he holds a lance.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ee-hee-a-duks-chee-a (He Who Ties His Hair Before)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Crow Indians; Clothing and dress; Headdresses
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 58. Chief of a band of the Crow Indians wearing a long feathered headdress over his natually long hair. His headdress is decorated with beaded embroidery and feathers. He is wearing face and body paint and a buffalo skin robe with embroidery. He is wearing a peace medal and several beaded necklaces.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Bi-eets-e-cure (the Very Sweet Man)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Crow Indians; Clothing and dress; Indian beadwork
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 59. Side portrait of a Crow warrior. He is wearing a very elaborately embroidered robe. The robe is decorated with war scenes, and beaded quillwork. He is also wearing various forms of feathers in his hair and multiple earrings.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ba-da-ah-tchon-du (He Who Jumps Over Everything)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Crow Indians; Clothing and dress; Indian embroidery; Indian beadwork; Headdresses
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 60. Portrait of a Crow chief from the back. He is shown wearing a very elaborate headdress of Eagle plumes, an elaborate robe with painted war scenes from his battles and body paint. Ermine tails and beaded embroidery also decorate the robe. He wears bands at his wrists and elbow and he holds a lance.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kitch-ee
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Indian women; Crow Indians; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 61. Portait of a Crow woman, wife a a chief, holding an eagle tail fan in her hand. She is wearing an embroidered robe over a dress, several strands of beads, earrings and some face paint. Her hair parted down the middle and worn loose.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Hah-chan-ko-ta
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Crow Indians; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Bow and arrow; Shields; Indian weapons
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 62. A Crow warrior portrait in full war dress and war paint. His skirt is made of feathers with a wide leather belt that has a otter skin tobacco sac tucked into it. He is holding a bow and arrow and has a large shield and bow and quiver set slung over his shoulders. There are several beaded necklaces around his neck and one with large grizzly bear claws. His hair is in several braids and he has various feathers in his hair.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Pa-ris-ka-roo-pa (the Two Crows)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Crow Indians; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Indian embroidery; Headdresses
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 63. Portrait of the head chief of the Crow tribe in elaborate dress. He is wearing an animal skin tunic with painted war scenes, beaded embroidery and hair locks. His hair extends to the ground and his large heeaddress is made of the entire skin of a war eagle. He is wearing face paint in horizonatal stripes and multiple earrings.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ka-ris-ka-roo-pa, the younger
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Crow Indians; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Indian embroidery
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 64. Portrait of a Crow wise man and counselor. He is wearing an embroidered animal skin robe, leggings, body paint and a feathered headdress.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Chah-ee-chopes (the Four Wolves)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Crow Indians; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 65. Chief of a band of the Crow Indians. He is wearing a fur robed and a blanket. His hair is very long. He has several feathers in his hair, face paint and several beaded necklaces, with the skin of a small animal hanging from one strand.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Duhk-gits-o-oh-shee (the Red Bear)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Crow Indians; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 66. Portrait of a distinguished Crow warrior. He is in full body paint, muliply beaded necklaces and holds a pipe and tobacco bag in one hand. He is wearing a painted or embroidered animal skin robe. His hair is worn long and loose.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Nee-hee-o-woo-tis (the Wolf on the Hill)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Cheyenne Indians; Manners and customs; Tobacco pipes
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 67. Portrait of the first chief of the Sienne tribe. He is shown wearing an tunic with an abundance of scalp locks, beaded embroidery. He is wearing feathers in his hair, many strands of beaded necklaces , one with a large medallion. He is wearing face paint and is holding a large pipe and what appears to be a fur robe.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Pla-nee
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Indian woman; Cheyenne Indians; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Indian beadwork
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 68. Portrait of a Shienne woman, and the wife a chief. She is wearing an animal skin dress embroidered with beaded quillwork. Her hair is in several braids and she wears multiply strands of beaded necklaces. She has face paint on her cheeks and she wears wrist cuffs.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Hee-wan-e-tax
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Cheyenne Indians; Manners and customs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 69. The great Orator and wise man of the Shienne tribe, wearing a buffalo robe with painted war scenes. He is said to have been a doctor and counselor to the chief. He is wearing several strands of beaded necklaces, several earrings and a small, feathered headdress.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Stan-au-pat (the Bloody Hand)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Arikara Indians; Manners and customs; Indian beadwork
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 70. Portrait of a chief of the Riccarree tribe, holding a large shield decorated with feathers. He is earing a heavily embroidered tunic with beaded quillwork embroidery, two rosettes and hair locks on his sleeves. He is wearing several strands of beaded necklaces, several earrings and is holding a knife, possibly a scalping knife and seems to be holding a bow and arrow set.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kah-beck-ee (the Twin)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Indian women; Arikara Indians; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 71. Portrait of a Riccarree woman in a buffalo hide dress. Her hair is parted down the middle, loose and she wears numerous earrings and an abundance of beads.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Pah-ta-coo-sah (He Who Strikes)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Arikara Indians; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Indian weapons
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 72. Portrait of a celebrated Riccarree warrior in full war dress. He is carrying his bow and arrow set, his decorated shield and his quiver, made of embroidered animal skin. He wears piercings in his septum and ears. He wears a small headdress of animal hair and feathers in his hair.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kut-sa-ra (the Jumper)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Arikara Indians; Indian weapons; Bow and arrow
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 73. Portrait of a Riccarree warrior wrapped in an embroidered buffalo robe, and carrying his bow and quiver slung across his back.

rdf:Description.dc:title: P'shan-p'shaw (Sweet Scented Grass)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Indian women; Arikara Indians; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 74. Portrait of a young Riccarree woman. She is wearing an elaborate dress of two mountain sheep skins and an embroidered buffalo skin robe. Her tunic or dress is embroidered with beaded rossettes, painted scenes. She wears multiple strands of beaded necklaces and earrings. There is a small area of face paint on her forehead.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Eehk-tohk-pah-she-pee-shaw (the Black Mocasin)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Older Indians; Hidatsa Indians; Clothing and dress; Tobacco pipes
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 75. Portrait of the head chief of the Minataree tribe. He is seated, wrapped in an animal skin robe, in full face paint and smoking a pipe. He was said to be 105 years old at the time of this portrait.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ee-a-chin-chee-a (the Red Thunder)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Hidatsa Indians; Manners and customs; Indian weapons; Body painting; Bow and arrow
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 76. Portrait of a young warrior and son of Eehk-tohk-pah-she-pee-shaw. He is in full war dress and war paint. He is wearing leggings, and his shield and quiver are slung across his back. He is holding his bow and arrow set in one hand. He is wearing face and body paint, and multiple earrings.

rdf:Description.dc:title: P'shun-shun(the Handsome Man)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Hidatsa Indians; Indian beadwork
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 77. Portrait of a young man in a richly embroidered tunic with beaded rosettes and hair locks on the sleeves. He wears an embroidered robe over his tunic, several strands of beads and several earrings. His hair is separted with leather stands and he has several feathers in his hair.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Seet-see-be-ah (the Mid-day Sun)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Indian women; Hidatsa Indians; Clothing and dress; Indian embroidery; Indian beadwork
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 78. Portrait of an young, unmarried girl in a mountian sheep skin dress. Her dress is embellished with beaded embroidery. She wears beaded necklaces, several earrings and holds an Eagle tail fan in her hand.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kee-o-kuk (the Running Fox)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Sauc Indians; Manners and customs; Indian embroidery; Indian weapons; Tomahawks
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 79. Portrait of the head chief of the Saukie tribe, known for his eloquence in speaking. He is shown wearing a ??????? fringed with scalp locks with a blanket or robe thrown over his shoulder. He has an animal skin pouch (possibly for tobacco) tucked into his belt and he is carrying a tomahawk with a scalp attached to the end. He is wearing a necklace made of grizzly bear claws, as well as other strands of beads and multiple earrings. He is wearing elaborate face paint on a shaven head and appears to be wearing a hair roach made of dyed animal hair and a single feather.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Pash-ee-pa-ho (the Swimmer)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Sauc Indians; Manners and customs; Indian weapons
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 80. Portrait of a distinguished War Chief of the Saukie tribe wearing body and face paint, a hair dress made of animal hair and feathers. He is holding a war club in one hand and a shield, decorated with feathers in the other. He wears multiple earrings, several strands of beads, a peace medal, and wrist bands. Attached to his tunic and pants is a large gathering of feathers and the skin of a bird.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Bid-dee
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Indian women; Sauc Indians; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 81. A Saukie woman wrapped in a heavily embroidered robe. Her hair is parted down the middle and braided and she wears several earrings and multiple stands of beads. Her dress is also beaded. She is the wife of chief Keeokuk.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Muk-a-tah-Mish-o-ka-kaik (the Black Hawk)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Sauc Indians; Manners and customs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 82. Portait of the War Chief of the Saukie tribe. He is wearing a leather jackey with fringe and scalp locks. His head is shaved and he is wearing a roach headdress, several beaded necklaces and large earrings. He is holding skin of a talisman of a fallen chief in his hand.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Nah-se-us-kuk (the Whirling Thunder)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Sauk Indians; Indians in art; Body painting
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 83. Portrait of the eldest son of the War Chief Black Hawk. His body is fully painted, and he wears paint on his cheeks and scalp. He has a shaved head and wears a raoch headdress. He wears several earrings and many beaded neckalces. He has cuffs at his elbows and wrists, wears a large decorated belt and has a blanket thrown over his shoulders.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Pash-ee-pa-ho (the Swimmer)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Sauk Indians; Manners and customs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 84. A famous warrior and son of an elder warrior of the same name. He is shown here holding a ball and chain and hand printss painted on his upper torso. He wears leggings and an embroidered breechclout. Many bands at his wrists and elbows. His head is shaved and he wears a roach headdress, face paint and several earrings. he is also wearing an interesting neck ornamentation.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Nah-pope (the Soup)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Sauk Indians; Manners and customs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 85. Portrait of a warrior taken prision with Black Hawk. He is wearing body paint, beaded necklaces and a kilt or loanclout with a leather belt. He is holding a ball and chain and is wearing a coup feather in his hair and earrings.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Wah-pe-kee-suck (the White Cloud)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America ; Clothing and dress; Sauk Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 86. Portrait of a man taken prisioner with Black Hawk. He is shown here wearing a hide garment with fringe ornamentation. He is wearing a cloth sash around his waist an embroidered and fringed sash across his upper torso.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ah-mou-a (the Whale)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Sauk Indians; Indian weapons; Tobacco pipes; Lances; Shields; Weapons
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 87. Portrait of a celebrated warrior of his tribe. He is wearing leggings, war paint, a grizzly claw necklace and a neck ornament made of animal hair. He wears bands at his wrists and elbows. He carries a lance, a shield and a war club. Tucked into his belt are two feathered pipes. In his hair are four feathers and he has some elements of face paint.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Wa-quath-ee-qua (the Buck's Wife)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Indian women; Sauk Indians; Clothing and dress; Indian beadwork
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 88. Portrait of a warrior's wife. She is wrapped in an animal skin hide and wearing many strands of beads. Her hair is in braids and she is wearing numerous earrings.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mee-sow-wahk (the Deer's Hair)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Sauk Indians; Indian beadwork; Indian weapons; Bow and arrow
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 89. Portrait of a Saukie boy, son of the head chief Keeokuk. He is wearing an animal skin tunic with scalp locks. He wears the skin of an animal in decoration, many strands of beads, a peace medal, a necklace made of grizzly bear claws. His head is shaved, he wears a roach headdress, earrings, face paint and he carries his bow and arrow set.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Lay-law-she-kaw (He Who Goes Up the River)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Shawnee Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 90. An aged man and head chief of the tribe. The rims of his ears curiously separated and elongated for the purpose ofsuspending a protrusion of ornaments.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kay-tee-qua (the Female Eagle)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Indian women; Shawnee Indians; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 91. Portait of an young Shawnee girl wrapped in an embroidered blanket or robe. She is wearing several beaded necklaces and has painted ornamentation on her cheeks.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Pah-tee-coo-saw (the Straight Man)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Shawnee Indians; Indian weapons; Rifles
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 92. Portrait of a Shawnee warrior with his rifle. He is wearing a tunic with fringe or fringe scalp locks. He has a sash at his waist and vertical and horizontal facepaint on his face. His head is wrapped in a cloth headdress.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ten-aqua-ta-way (the Open Door)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Shawnee Indians; Manners and customs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 93. Portrait of a Shawano man called the ""Shawnee Prophet"", and the brother of Tecumseh. He was blind in one eye and is depicted holding his ""sacred string of beans"" in one hand and fire in the other. He is wearing body paint, leather cuffs at his elbows and wrists and a large woven belt. He is wearing an animal fur over his torso and numerous strands of beads. He is also wearing several earrings and arrows in his ears.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Shoo-de-ga-cha (the Smoke)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Ponca Indians; Indian weapons; Lances
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 94. Portrait of a dignified head chief of the Puncah tribe. His wearing an embroidered buffalo skin robe. He is wearing body paint, beaded necklaces, a peace medal, leather cuffs at his wrists and is holding a lance in one hand.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Hongs-kay-dee (the Great Chief)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Ponca Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 95. Portrait of a young Ponca man, son of the Chief Shoondegacha. He is wearing a hide robe, decorated with an Eagle's tail. He is wearing body paint, multiple strands of beads, many beaded earrings and face paint. In his hair is a headdress of multiple feather types, animal hair and an arrow.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mong-shong-shaw (the Bending Willow)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Indian women; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 96. Portrait of a young Puncah girl wrapped in an embroidered hide robe. She is wearing numerous strands of beads, earrings and a painted decorations on each cheek. Her hair is worn loose and is parted down the middle. This portrait was completed the day after her marriage.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Hee-la-dee (the Pure Fountain)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Indian women; Menominee Indians; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 97. Portrait of a Puncah woman wrapped in a decorated robe. She is wearing body paint, many beaded necklaces and earrings and cuffs.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mah-kee-me-teuv (the Grizzly Bear)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Indian weapons; Tobacco pipes; Menominee Indians; Manners and customs; Weapons
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 98. Portrait of a distinguished Menomonie man. He is wrapped in a robe and is wearing paint on his face and body. He wears numerous strands of beads and a very large symbol, possibly made of beads on his chest. His headdress consists of numerous feathers and wrapped cloth. He holds a large pipe in one hand and his war club in the other.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Chee-ma-nah-na-quet (the Great Cloud)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Menominee Indians; Indian weapons; Weapons
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 99. Son of a Menominee chief wearing an embroidered robe and holding a war club in his arms. He is wearing face paint, several strands of beads, and various types of feathers in his hair.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Me-cheet-e-neuh (the Wounded Bear's Shoulder)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Indian women; Menominee Indians; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 100. Portrait of a Menominee woman, the wife of Mah-kee-me-teuv. She is wearing a large, embroidered robe and numerous strands of beads and necklaces. She has face paint on her cheeks, chin and forehead.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Chesh-ho-tong
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Indian weapons; Menominee Indians; Weapons
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 101. Portrait of a young Menominee warrior. He is wearing leggings anda tunic with an embroidered sash. In his hair are several feathers and his hair is worn loose. He is holding his war club.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Wah-chees
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Menominee Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 102. Portrait of a young Menominee man playing a flute. He is wearing a peace medal, several strands of beads, a breechclout and an embroidered robe. He is holding a tomahawk. His headdress consists of feathers and animal hair. His hair is in braids.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Raw-no-way-wah-krah (the Loose Pipe Stem)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Oto Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 103. Portrait of a secondary chief of the Oto tribe. He is wearing an animal skin robe with an embroidered or painted war scene. He is wearing body paint and a large eagle quill headdress.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Wa-ro-nee-saw (the Surrounder)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Oto Indians; Calumets
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 104. Portrait of the head chief of the Oto tribe wearing a tunic made of Grizzly bear skin, claws and emrboidery. He is wearing a headdress of Eagles quillls, face paint and is holding his Calumet.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Klay-net
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Indian women; Indian children; Dogs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 105. Portrait of an Ottoe woman carrying her child, implements and a domestic dog. She is wearing a very large robe and earrings.

rdf:Description.dc:title: La-du kee-a (the Buffalo Bull)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Indian weapons; Pawnee Indians; Manners and customs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 106. Portrait of a celebrated Pawnee warrior in his war dress and war paint, holding his bow and arrow. He is wearing multple strands of beads, a peace medal, many earrings and is wrapped in an animal skin robe. His head is shaved and he wears what appears to be a headdress made from animal hair.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Loo-ra-wee-ree-coo (the Bird that Goes to War)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Pawnee Indians; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Tomahawks
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 107. Portrait of a Pawnee warrior holding his tomahawk. He is wearing many strands of beads, earrings, body paint and a decorated robe with war scenes. His head is shaved and he wears a headdress made of animal hair.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ah-sha-le-coots-a (the Mole in the Forehead)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Pawnee Indians; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Indian weapons; Bow and arrow
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 108. Portrait of a Pawnee warrior in war dress and war paint. He is wearing an embroidered animal skin robe, body paint, cuffs at his wrists, several strands of beads and necklaces, a peace medal. His head is shaved and he wears a headdress made of animal hair and several large earrings. He carries his bow and arrow set.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quet-la-hoo
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Indian women; Indian children; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 109. Portrait of a Pawnee woman and wife of Loo-ra-wee-ree-coo. She is holding her infant in an embroidered cradle or papoose. She is wrapped in a robe and is wearing many strands of jewelry and beads and multiple earrings.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Lee-shaw-loo-lah-le-hoo (the Big Elk)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Pawnee Indians; Manners and customs; Tobacco use
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 110. Portrait of a secondary chief of the Pawnee tribe. He is wearing an oramented robe with battle scenes and embroidery, full body paint and a headdress made of war eagle feathers and ermine. He is depicted smoking a large pipe.

rdf:Description.dc:title: L'har-ree-tar-rushe (the Ill Natured Man)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America ; Clothing and dress; Pawnee Indians; Manners and customs; Tomahawks
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 111. Portrait of a celebrated Pawnee warrior with his pipe tomahawk. He is dressed in full war costume. He is wearing an embroidered animal skin robe, many beaded necklaces, a large peace medal, body and face paint. He is wearing multiple earrings and a headdress made of animal hair over his shaved head.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Shon-ki-hee-ga (the Horse Chief)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Pawnee Indians; Manners and customs; Tomahawks
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 112. Portrait of the head chief of the Pawnee of the Platte wearing an embroidered animal skin robe, body paint, many beaded necklaces and earrings. He has a shaved head and a headdress made of horse hair. He is holding a tomahawk in his hand.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Haw-chee-ka-sug-a (the Osage killer)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Missouri Indians; Tobacco pipes
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 113. Portrait of a chief of the Missouri tribe. He is wrapped in an embroidered robe, wearing a necklace made of grizzly bear claws, a feathered headdress, body paint. He is holding a tobacco pouch in one hand and a large pipe in the other.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ki-ho-ga-wah-shu-she (the Very Brave chief)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Omaha Indians; Indian weapons; Shields; Bow and arrow; Tobacco pipes
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 114. Portrait of the head chief of the Omaha tribe. He is wearing an elaborate robe, a feather headdress with horns and necklaces of beads and grizzly bear claws. He is carrying a large shield, bow and quiver set and a large pipe.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Wi-neech-ee (the Robin)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Indian women; Omaha Indians; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 115. Portrait of a woman from the Omaha tribe wearing an embroidered dress and robe. She is holding an eagle's tail fan and an embroidered purse. Her hair is braided and she is wearing small amounts of face paint.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Nom-ba-mon-nee (the Double Walker)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Omaha Indians; Manners and customs; Indian weapons; Shields; Bow and arrow; Weapons
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 117. Portrait of a famous Omaha warrior in war dress and war paint. He is carrying his shield, a bow and quiver set and a war club. He is wearing a feathered headdress and kilt made of war eagle plums.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Om-pa-ton-ga (the Big Elk)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Omaha Indians; Indian weapons; Bow and arrow
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 118. Portrait of an Omaha warrior in a decorated buffalo robe, carrying his bow and quiver set. He is wearing single feathers in his hair.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Man-sha-qui-ta (the Little Soldier)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Omaha Indians; Indian weapons; Bow and arrow
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 119. Portrait of an Omaha man with his bow and quiver set. He is wearing embroidered leggings, multiple beaded necklaces, a necklace with grizzly bear claws, face paint, earrings and feathers in his hair.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Eeh-tow-ess-ka-zeet (He Who Has Eyes Behind Him)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Cree Indians; Indian weapons; Bow and arrow
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 120. Portrait of a distinguished warrior of the Knisteneux or Cree tribe. He is wearing an animal skin robe over an embroidered tunic with scalp locks and is carrying his bow and quiver set. He has two small braids in his hair and has feathers in his hair.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tsee-mount (A Great Wonder)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Indian women; Cree Indians; Clothing and dress; Shields
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 121. Portrait of a Knisteneux woman, wife of a warrior. She is wearing an animal skin dress, embroidered with beadwork. She is holding a shield.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tchong-tas-sab-bee (the Black Dog)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Osage Indians; Manners and customs; Tobacco pipes; Indian weapons; Tomahawks
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 122. Portrait of the war chief of the Osage tribe with his pipe and tomahawk in his hands. He is wearing a blanket, multiple strands of beads, a peace medal, bands at his elbows and wrists, and earrings. His head is shaved and his hairpiece consists of animal hair and a single feather. He was known to be six feet tall and blind in one eye.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tal-lee
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Osage Indians; Indian weapons; Shields; Bow and arrow
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 123. Portrait of the most distinguished warrior of the Osage tribe. He is carrying his shield, bow and quiver set. He is wearing a peace medal, some strands of beads, and multiple earrings. He has a shaved head and is wearing a large headdress with animal hair and a feather.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ko-ha-tunk-a (the Big Crow)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Osage Indians; Manners and customs; Indian weapons; Bow and arrow; Weapons
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 124. Portrait of an Osage warrior in his war dress with his bow and quiver slung over his back. His head is shaved and he is wearing an animal hair headdress with a single feather. He is wearing leggings, a woven belt, body paint, many strands of beads and multiple earrings. He holds a war club.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Clermont
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America ; Clothing and dress; Osage Indians; Manners and customs; Indian weapons; Weapons
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 125. Seated portrait of the head chief of the Osage tribe with his large war club. He is wearing leggings embroidered and decorated with multiple scalp locks, full body paint, beaded necklaces, a peace medal and earrings. His head is shaved and he is wearing a headdress with animal hair, a single feather and small amounts of painted ornamentation.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Wah-chee-te
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Indian women; Indian children
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 126. Portrait of a seated Osage woman and child. She is wearing a wrapped, embroidered robe, strands of beads, earrings and her hair is worn loose.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mun-ne-pus-kee (He Who Is Not Afraid)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Indian weapons; Osage Indians; Manners and customs; Lances
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 127. Portrait of a favorite Osage warrior in war dress and paint. He is wearing leggings, an embroidered belt, beaded necklaces, and many earrings. He is in full body paint, has a shaved head with a feather headdress. He has three circular ornamentations on his face and he is holding his lance.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Nah-com-ee-shee (Man of the Bed)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America ; Clothing and dress; Indian weapons; Osage Indians; Bow and arrow
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 128. Portrait of an Osage warrior in war dress, war paint and holding his bow and arrows. He is wearing leggings, full body paint, a fur necklace, a shaved head with face paint and a single attached feather.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Os-ce-o-la (the Black Drink)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Seminole Indians; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 129. Portrait of a Seminole warrior. He is wearing leggings, an embroidered tunic with a wide belt or sash. His dress appears European, and he is carrying a pouch with his gun powder horn. His headpiece consists of multiple feathers and he wears several strands of beads of varying sizes.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mic-e-no-pah
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Seminole Indians; Manners and customs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 130. Portrait of the head chief of the Seminoles during the Seminole War. His dress is European in nature and he is depicted wearing leggings, tall boots, a ruffle blouse and is holding a robe. His hat or headdress is adorned with a single feather and he wears beaded necklaces and face paint on his cheeks.

rdf:Description.dc:title: A Seminolee woman and child
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Indian women; Indian children; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Seminole Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 131. Depiction of a Seminole woman and her child. She is seated, wearing a robe, multiple strands of beaded necklaces, and earrings.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ee-mat-la
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Older Indians; Seminole Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 132. Portrait of an elderly Seminole chief. He is depicted here holding a pipe, and wearing a European jacket and an animal skin robe.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ye-how-lo-gee (the Cloud)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Indian weapons; Weapons; Seminole Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 133. Portrait of a Semiole warrior wrapped in a large robe adorned with a metal ornamentation. He appears to be carrying a weapon and his ammunition bag. He is wearing a headdress or hat with a single feather.

rdf:Description.dc:title: La-Shee (the Licker)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Rifles
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 134

rdf:Description.dc:title: Os-ce-o-la (the Black Drink)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Indian children; Indian weapons; Bow and arrow
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 136. Portait of a young Seminole wearing leggings, many beaded necklaces, woven belts, body paint and holding his bow and arrows.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Seminole woman
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North Americas; Indian women; Indian children; Seminole Indians; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 136b. Portrait of a Seminole woman with her child in a papoose. She is dressed in tunic with scalp locks, beaded necklaces and earrings.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ee-sha-co-nee (the Bow and Quiver)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Indian weapons; Shields; Weapons; Tobacco pipes
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 137. Portrait of a Seminole warrior, seated and smoking a large pipe. He appears to be in full war paint and dress and is depicted with his shield and weapons.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ha-nee (the Beaver)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Comanche Indians; Clothing and dress; Bow and arrow
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 138. Seated man with chin in hand. He holds arrows and a pipe in his other hand, and wears necklaces, wrist cuffs, face paint and arm tattoos.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ish-a-ro-yeh (He Who Carries a Wolf)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Comanche Indians; Kings and rulers; Bow and arrow; Tomahawks
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 139. Man seated on ground, facing left. He wears fringed pants, moccasins, a feather, a beaded belt and facial tattoos. He holds a tomahawk and a bow and arrow.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tah-wah-que-nah (the Mountain of Rocks)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Comache Indians; Clothing and dress; Bow and arrow; Shields
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 140. Man stands holding bow and arrows, with shield and quiver full of arrows. He wears a furry breech clout, wrist cuffs, braids, and tattoos.

rdf:Description.dc:title: His-oo-san-chees
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Comanche Indians; Bow and arrow; Shields
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 141. Man stands holding bow and arrows, with shield and quiver full of arrows. He wears a furry breech clout, wrist cuffs, braids, and tattoos.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Wife of Tah-weh-que-nah
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Comanche Indians; Clothing and dress; Indian women
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 142. Woman stands wrapped in animal skin robe. She wears many necklaces and holds an implement made of feathers. There are two small animals (dogs?) wrapped in her robe.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Comanche girls
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Comanche Indians; Indian children; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 143. One girl stands behind another girl, holding hands. They wear dresses with fringe and necklaces, and decorative face paint. They are sisters, children of the head chief of the tribe.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Wee-tar-ro-shar-ro
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Wichita Indians; Kings and rulers; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 144. An elderly Pawnee Pict (Wichita) chief stands holding long pipe. He wears a medallion, necklaces, two feathers, arm tattoos, and a robe painted with battle scenes. From the back of the drawing: ""A small tribe, living in one village, on the Red River, near the Eastern base of the Rocky Mountains. Latitude 32 [degrees].""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Sky-se-ro-ka
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Wichita Indians; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 145. Pawnee Pict (Wichita) man stands wearing animal skin robe decorated with battle scenes. He also wears a medallion, necklaces, leggings, and small braids in his hair.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Shee-de-a (Wild Sage)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Wichita Indians; Indian women; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 146. Pawnee Pict (Wichita) young woman wearing animal skin robe and many necklaces and earrings.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kah-keet-se (The Thighs)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Wichita Indians; Indian women; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 147. Pawnee Pict (Wichita) woman wearing animal skin robe. Her chest and arm are intricately tattooed.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ush-ee-kits (He Who Fights with a Feather)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Waco Indians; Kings and rulers; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 148. Waco chief with large pendant and earrings stands wearing painted animal skin robe. He has arm tattoos and feathers in his hair.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kits-e-ro-a
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Waco Indians; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 149. Two figures stand facing each other. One, with back turned, has long hair, many earrings and decorated robe. The second, smaller person wears a tunic. From verso: ""Wife and child of the chief on the foregoing page [Ush-ee-kits].""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kots-a-toh-a
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Waco Indians; Clothing and dress; Spears; Bow and arrow
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 150. Warrior stands with spear, animal skin robe, and quiver full of arrows slung around his shoulder. He also wears a large round pendant, a claw pendant, many earrings, and a feather.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Notch-ee-ning-a (No Heart)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Iowa Indians; Kings and rulers; Clothing and dress; Shields; Spears
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 151. No Heart, an Iowa chief, stands holding spear and shield. He wears a bear claw necklace, painted animal skin robe, and fabric wrapped around his head.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mu-hu-she-kaw (The White Cloud)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Iowa Indians; Kings and rulers; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 152. White Cloud, an Iowa chief, stands holding pipe. His animal skin robe is painted with battle scenes. He also wears a bear claw necklace, many earrings, a headband, and tattoos.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Pah-ta-choo-chee (The Shooting Cedar)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Iowa Indians; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 153. Man stands with war club. He wears leggings, beaded belt, bear claw necklace, earrings and headwrap.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Red-Jacket
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Seneca Indians; Kings and rulers; Clothing and dress; Red Jacket, Seneca chief, approximately 1756-1830
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 154. Red Jacket, prominent chief, stands holding tomahawk and pointing. He wears a woven belt, robe, large pendant (peace medal?) and headwrap with feathers.

rdf:Description.dc:title: The Hard Hickory
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Seneca Indians; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 154b. Man stands holding pipe. He wears an intricately designed sash and belt, tunic, necklaces and headwrap with feathers.

rdf:Description.dc:title: The Good Hunter
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Seneca Indians; Clothing and dress; Tomahawks
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 155. Man stands holding pipe tomahawk. He wears a robe, beaded belt, necklaces, and thin braids in his hair. He has face paint and a headwrap.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Bod-a-sin
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Delaware Indians; Kings and rulers; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 156. Bod-a-sin, Delaware chief, stands holding rifle. He wears a collared shirt, beaded belt, powder horn, bag, and large pendant.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Non-on-da-gon
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Delaware Indians; Kings and rulers; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 157. Also a Delaware chief. He stands wearing a long jacket, headwrap, and thin braids in his hair. His septum (nose) is pierced with a hoop. He holds a rifle under his arm.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kit-tee-kat-tee
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Delaware Indians; Indian women; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 158. Wife of Bod-a-sin. She stands wrapped in a decorated animal skin robe, wearing many necklaces and earrings.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Chief Daniel Bread
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Oneida Indians; Kings and ruler; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 159. Oneida chief stands holding pipe or tomahawk. He wears an animal skin robe, a large pendant, and a headwrap with feathers.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Oneida woman
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Oneida Indians; Indian women
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 160. Woman stands in animal skin robe. She has two thin braids in her hair. Sister of Chief Daniel Bread.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Cu-sick
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Tuscarora Indians; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 161. Man in long, European-style coat stands holding hankerchief. He wears a woven belt and a cravat or scarf. From verso: ""Tuskarorra. ?026Son of the chief?026.a Baptist preacher.""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kruts-taw-no (Jim Hunter)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Micmac Indians; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 162. Man stands in leggings and long coat. He wears decorated armbands and headband, belt and sash. He wears many necklaces, including a bear claw pendant, powder horn, bag, and belt. He holds a staff or the end of a long rifle. From verso: ""A famous moose hunter, and also distinguished as a warrior in the last war between England and the U. States.""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Not-a-way
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Iroquois Indians; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 163. Portrait of an Iroquois chief. He is wearing a large feathered headdress, many strands of beads, a peace medal, wrist and arm bands, leggings and a wide sash at his waist. He is holding a weapon.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ches-a-kah-chee
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America ; Indian women
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 164. Portrait of an Iroquois woman wrapped in a blanket.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Nox-to-yeh
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Iroquois Indians; Clothing and dress; Indian weapons
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 165. Portrait of a young Iroquois warrior, wrapped in a blanket and holding his bow and arrow set. He has single feathers in his hair.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tsa-hau-mix-en (The Rock that Slides Down the Hill)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Indians weapons; Bow and arrow
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 166. Portrait of a Nayas Indian holding his bow and arrows. He is wearing a skin tunic, his ear has been extended. He has a circular block of wood passing through his underlip, a custom peticular to the Nayas tribe.

rdf:Description.dc:title: A Nayas woman
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Indian women; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs
