rdf:Description.dc:title: Views of ancient monuments in Central America, Chiapas and Yucatan
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Antiquities; Idols and images
rdf:Description.dc:description: Title page with decorative border and insignia of author's initials

rdf:Description.dc:title: Outline map of Central America & Yucatan shewing the situation of ruined cities & monuments visited by Messrs. Stephens & Catherwood in the years 1839, 1840, 1841, 1842
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Stephens, John Lloyd, 1805-1852; Catherwood, Frederick; Travel; Antiquities; Extinct cities
rdf:Description.dc:description: ""The dotted red line shows the route."" Prime meridian: Greenwich.
rdf:Description.dc:coverage: Central America; Mexico; Central America--Yucat?n Peninsula 1839-1842

rdf:Description.dc:title: Idol, at Copan
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Antiquities; Idols and images; Jungles
rdf:Description.dc:description: Plate I. Tall stone statue in jungle setting. Intricately carved figure of woman with arms folded at chest, decorated robe, bracelets, and large headdress.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Pyramidal building and fragments of sculpture, at Copan
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Antiquities; Maya architecture; Jungles
rdf:Description.dc:description: Plate II. Jungle scene featuring terraced pyramid-shaped structure made of stone bricks. It is overgrown with trees. In the foreground, several sculptured stone ornaments: a monkey skull, the busts of a warrior and a chieftain, and sacrificial stone.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Back of an idol, at Copan
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Antiquities; Idols and images; Jungles
rdf:Description.dc:description: Plate III. Carved stone structure, featuring five wreaths with hieroglyphs, stands in the jungle. Two men sit at its base.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Broken idol, at Copan
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Antiquities; Idols and images; Jungles
rdf:Description.dc:description: Plate IV. Two large parts of broken statue, carved with humanlike figures and hieroglyphs, lie in a small pond in the jungle. Dense forest and a terraced mound in background. A deer jumps over a stone to the left.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Idol and altar, at Copan
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Antiquities; Idols and images
rdf:Description.dc:description: Plate V. Statue and sacrificial stone, both carved with grotesque features. Stone (or altar) carving has fangs and distended eyes.

rdf:Description.dc:title: General view of Palenque
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Antiquities; Maya architecture
rdf:Description.dc:description: Plate VI. Landscape of the ruins of Palenque, in present day Chiapas (Mexico). Prominent in the image is the palace, a pyramidal mound with a house at the top, lush vegetation and a very high hill. Two men sit at the foreground.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Principal court of the palace at Palenque
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Antiquities; Maya architecture
rdf:Description.dc:description: Plate VII, upper subject. Entrance to palace, with several bas-relief statues of human figures on columns and near steps. Trees grow on roof. Several men sit in front of steps.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Interior of casa, No. III, Palenque
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Antiquities; Maya architecture; Palenque Indians
rdf:Description.dc:description: Plate VII, lower subject. Interior archway of palace, made of stones. A man sits on a step.

rdf:Description.dc:title: General view of Las Monjas, at Uxmal
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Antiquities; Indians of Mexico; Maya architecture
rdf:Description.dc:description: Plate VIII. Landscape scene of valley with group of buildings (""Las Monjas"" or ""Nuns"") and mounds (acropolis), as seen from the Governor's House (Casa del Gobernador). Several men work in the foreground.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ornament over the principal doorway, Casa del Gobernador, Uxmal
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Antiquities; Maya architecture; Decoration and ornament
rdf:Description.dc:description: Plate IX. Elaborately carved stone wall, over doorway.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Archway, Casa del Gobernador, Uxmal
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Antiquities; Maya architecture; Decoration and ornament; Indians of Mexico
rdf:Description.dc:description: Plate X. Arched gateway with elaborate stone carvings. The carvings are of geometric patterns and masks. Part of gateway has been blocked up with stones. At base of gateway, two men, one woman and two children stand regarding two snakes.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Gateway of the great Teocallis, Uxmal
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Antiquities; Maya architecture; Decoration and ornament; Indians of Mexico
rdf:Description.dc:description: Plate XI. The Teocallis, also called House of the Diviner or Dwarf's House, sits on pyramidal mound. A grand stone structure with intricate stone carvings at the gateway. Several people and a dog gather outside the entrance.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ornament over the gateway of the great Teocallis, Uxmal
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Antiquities; Maya architecture; Decoration and ornament; Indians of Mexico
rdf:Description.dc:description: Plate XII. Elaborate stonework in front of and above an entrance to Teocallis, also called the House of the Diviner or the Dwarf's House. Much of wall carved into trellis design; above, the remants of statues and mask-like carvings. Several men sit in foreground.

rdf:Description.dc:title: General view of Uxmal, taken from the archway of Las Monjas, looking south
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Antiquities; Maya architecture; Indians of Mexico
rdf:Description.dc:description: Plate XIII. Landscape scene of Uxmal, Yucatan (Mexico). Several terraced mounds, dwellings and structures amid jungle. Scene includes Casa de la Vieja (Old Woman), Casa del Gobernador (Governor's House), Casa de las Tortugas (House of the Turtles) and Casa de Palomos (House of the Pigeons). In foreground, several people rest.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Portion of a building, Las Monjas, Uxmal
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Antiquities; Maya architecture; Decoration and ornament; Indians of Mexico
rdf:Description.dc:description: Plate XIV. Facade of building, including elaborately carved stone with serpent motif. Group of Indians in foreground.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Portion of la Casa de las Monjas, Uxmal
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Antiquities; Maya architecture; Decoration and ornament; Indians of Mexico
rdf:Description.dc:description: Plate XV. Elaborate stone carvings on facade of Las Monjas (the Nuns), with geometric, floral and serpent motifs. Group of Indians stand in foreground, many wearing white cotton tunics.

rdf:Description.dc:title: General view of Kabah
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Antiquities; Maya architecture; Indians of Mexico
rdf:Description.dc:description: Plate XVI. Landscape view of distant ruins of Kabah, with several large buildings and terraced mounds. In the foreground, a group of Indian men on a road carry a large rectangular object downhill. They are accompanied by a man in European dress. Many wear woven (straw?) hats.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Interior of the principal building at Kabah
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Antiquities; Maya architecture; Decoration and ornament,
rdf:Description.dc:description: Plate XVII. Interior of building overgrown with vines, with pointed archway and carved stonework at lower wall to the right.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Well and building at Sabachtsche
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Antiquities; Indians of Mexico;Manners and customs; Clothing and dress; Domestic life; Indian women; Wells
rdf:Description.dc:description: Plate XVIII. Exterior scene at well at the Rancho of Sabachtsche. Large group of Indians gather around well, mostly women and some children. Most have their own bucket or vase. Two people on horses in background.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Gateway at Labnah
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Antiquities; Maya architecture; Decoration and ornament; Indians of Mexico; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Plate XIX. Large archway or gateway with geometric stonework. Several Indians stand in front of building, most wearing woven (straw?) hats and white tunics.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Well at Bolonchen
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Antiquities; Wells; Indians of Mexico; Manners and customs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Plate XX. Interior of cavern or cave. A long, broad wooden ladder stands with its base in a pool of water. Many people on ladder carry buckets. Most wear straw hats and white shorts. One man stands near water with a torch.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Las Monjas, Chichen-Itza
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Antiquities; Maya architecture; Decoration and ornament; Indians of Mexico
rdf:Description.dc:description: Plate XXI. Facade of building with many intricate stone carvings, including curved ornaments and a rope motif. Trees grow on roof. Three men sit on a blanket in front of building.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Teocallis at Chichen-Itza
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Antiquities; Maya architecture
rdf:Description.dc:description: Plate XXII. Ruins of a stone building sit on top of terraced mound in forest. In the foreground, the head of a large animal statue lies on the ground.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Castle at Tuloom
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Antiquities; Maya architecture; Indians of Mexico
rdf:Description.dc:description: Plate XXIII. Cluster of stone buildings in forest, overgrown with trees. A large wall or set of steps leads to center building, with carvings and columns. Several Indian men work in foreground, clearing overgrowth and logs, most wearing straw hats and white tunics.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Temple at Tuloom
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Antiquities; Maya architecture; Indians of Mexico; Labor
rdf:Description.dc:description: Plate XXIV. Dilapidated ruins of one-story building, with trees behind and group of Indian men working in foreground. Two men in European dress stand by the crumbling building.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Colossal head, at Izamal
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Antiquities; Idols and images; Indians of Mexico
rdf:Description.dc:description: Plate XXV. Nighttime outdoor scene. Two men stand in front of large carving of face in a massive stone wall. One man holds a rifle and regards a cougar or large cat to the right. Full moon in the background.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Views of ancient monuments in Central America, Chiapas and Yucatan
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Catherwood, Frederick
rdf:Description.dc:format: 2 p. l., 24 p. 25 pl., map 55 cm Watercolors; Maps; Lithographs; Works of art Tiff
rdf:Description.dc:source: New York: Bartlett and Welford
rdf:Description.dc:relation: Edward E. Ayer Collection (Newberry Library) Edward E. Ayer Digital Collection (Newberry Library)
rdf:Description.dc:rights: All rights reserved by the Newberry Library. Permission to reproduce in any format must be requested in writing. Contact Photoduplication Department, Newberry Library, 60 W. Walton St., Chicago, IL 60610. Phone: 312-255-3566 E-mail: photoduplication@newberry.org

rdf:Description.dc:title: Earth lodge village scene
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mandan Indians; Dwellings; Earth houses; Manners and customs; Horses; Indians of North America; Villages
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 1. Crowded Mandan village scene, near Fort Clark. Many horses, some with riders, and two standing figures. Earth lodge, with people on top, in background along with items (skins?) held aloft on poles.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Reclining Indian viewing Fort Pierre
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 2. Prostrate man with buffalo robe, facing left. He is propped up on his arms and seems to be crawling.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Studies for the funeral scaffold of a Sioux chief
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Sioux Indians; Indian women; Rites and ceremonies; Tobacco use; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 3. Two variants of sitting smoker, with long pipe and animal skin robe. Also two variants of woman bent over, covered with robe.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Funeral scaffold of a Sioux chief
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Sioux Indians; Funeral rites and ceremonies; Indian women; Indian children; Indians of North America Tipis
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 4. A group of men and a woman with two small children congregate near a funeral scaffold (a platform on stilts). The men hold a staff, a long pipe, a rifle, and wear animal skin robes. Two domesticated dogs stand nearby. People, horses, and tipis in background.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Studies for the funeral scaffold of a Sioux chief
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Sioux Indians; Funeral customs and rites; Clothing and dress; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 5. Composite sketches used for Bodmer Drawing No. 4. Two variants of prostrate man, propped up on elbows and covered with robe or blanket. Three variants of back view of standing man, with robe, leggings, and holding a staff. One frontal view of standing man with robe. Also a preliminary sketch of group of men outside tipi.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mandans with dog sledges
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mandan Indians; Manners and customs; Dogsledding; Sleds; Dogs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 6. A winter scene, with two dogs pulling sled. A figure wrapped in blankets or skins walks with dogs, carrying bundle. Second figure, similarly wrapped, sits on sled with driving stick and other goods. Light sketches of other people and dogs in background.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Interior of a Mandan earth lodge
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mandan Indians; Dwellings; Earth houses; Tobacco use; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 7. Five men inside an earth lodge, smoking a pipe. Interior walls made of skins.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Hidatsa winter village
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Hidatsa Indians; Manners and customs; Sports; Clothing and dress; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 8. Outdoor scene with several people standing, wrapped in decorated skins and fur. Most men have feathers in hair. One figure on horse; others hold rifle, large basket, bucket, or play hoop-and-pole game.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Scalp dance of the Minatarres
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Hidatsa Indians; Rites and ceremonies; Dance; Clothing and dress; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 9. Large group of men and women (Hidatsa), assembled in circle, at ceremonial scalp dance. Group includes dogs, horses, birds, and children. People wear face paint, feathered headbands, claw necklaces, earrings, decorated blankets, animal skins and furs, roached hair, decorated leggings, and one man in split horn headband and long war bonnet. Some are dancing or singing, and two people hold long poles with scalps at ends. Others hold drums and mallets, arrows, rifles, and tomahawk.

rdf:Description.dc:title: M?hchsi-Nikha, a Mandan man
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mandan Indians; Clothing and dress; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 10. Man standing with red blanket or animal skin robe, decorated shirt, feather, holding club. His face has a blue tint.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Awascho-Dickfas, a Hidatsa man
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Hidatsa Indians; Clothing and dress; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 11. Rear-view portrait of standing man, the angle to better show his unusual feathered headgear and painted design on animal skin robe. Fur trim with extensions (tails) at cuffs of leggings.

rdf:Description.dc:title: An ethnographic collection
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Indian weapons; Lances; Feathers
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 12. Composite sketch of several implements and weapons of Indians from the Missouri River Valley. Included are a blade, knife, lance, club, eagle feather headdress, drum or shield with stuffed animal skins, roach (hair ornament), parfleche (rawhide bag), Sioux moccasins, quiver with bows and arrows, pipe tamper, pipestem, pipe, ball, hoop for hoop-and-pole game, bird-bone whistle.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ponca camp
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Ponca Indians; Dwellings; Tipis; Indians of North America; Canoes and canoeing
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 13. Small boat approaches small encampment of Ponca Indians near mouth of Niobara River in Nebraska. Tipis in background. Tangle of trees and logs on right.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Crow Indian men and horses
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Crow Indians; Clothing and dress; Indians of North America; Horses
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 14. Several men standing, sitting, or on horseback look towards one man at left. He wears elaborate headgear and points to the left.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Assiniboine camp
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Assiniboine Indians; Dwellings; Tipis; Indians of North America Horses; Dogs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 15; Several Native Americans outside the tipi of an Assiniboine chief, near Fort Union, North Dakota. Dogs with harnesses carry goods. Child plays with dog. Nets or traps hang on wooden poles. One man on horse.
rdf:Description.dc:coverage: North Dakota--Fort Union; Missouri River Valley

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mexkem?uastan, an Atsina chief
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Atsina Indians; Kings and rulers; Clothing and dress; Indians of North America Tribal chiefs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 16. Portrait of standing Atsina (sometimes called Gros Ventres of the Prairies) man, wrapped in skins and wearing quiver and earrings. He has fur-trimmed leggings, and holds a wrapped rifle. Knotted hair signifies his status as a medicine man. Same image as VAULT Ayer Art Bodmer, Drawing No. 17.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mexkem?uastan, an Atsina chief
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Atsina Indians; Kings and rulers; Clothing and dress; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 17. Portrait of standing Atsina (sometimes called Gros Ventres of the Prairies) man, wrapped in skins and wearing quiver and earrings. He has fur-trimmed leggings, and holds a wrapped rifle. Knotted hair signifies his status as a medicine man. Same image as VAULT Ayer Art Bodmer, Drawing No. 16.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Male study no. 1
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mandan Indians; Dance; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 18. Side view of man holding a staff or pole, crouching and facing right. Incorporated into Vignette XXV, ""Dance of the Mandan Indians.""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Figure in bison robe
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mandan Indians; Clothing and dress; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 19. View of back of figure wrapped in bison robe. Incorporated into Vignette XXV, ""Dance of the Mandan Indians.""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Male study no. 2
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mandan Indians; Dance; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 20; Side view of man holding pole, facing left and wearing hat or scarf on head. Incorporated into Vignette XXV, ""Dance of the Mandan Indians.""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Hidatsa men playing hoop-and-pole
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Hidatsa Indians; Clothing and dress; Sports; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 21. Detailed sketch of men playing recreational hoop-and-pole game. Leggings and animal skin clothing have fringe.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Male study no. 3
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mandan Indians; Dance; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 22. Crouching man, in breech cloth, holding pole. Incorporated into Vignette XXV, ""Dance of the Mandan Indians.""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Male study no. 4
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mandan Indians; Dance; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 23. Crouching man, in breechcloth and holding pole. Incorporated into Vignette XXV, ""Dance of the Mandan Indians.""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Male study no. 5
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mandan Indians; Dance; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 24. Back of crouching man, holding pole. Incorporated into Vignette XXV, ""Dance of the Mandan Indians.""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Maximilian's encounter with the Hidatsas
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Hidatsa Indians; Wied, Maximilian, Prinz von, 1782-1867; Bodmer, Karl, 1809-1893; Charbonneau, Toussaint, approximately 1758-approximately 1839; Indians of North America Horses
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 25. Prince Maximilian von Wied, Karl Bodmer, and David Dreidoppel being introduced to a Hidatsa chief by Fort Clark translator Toussaint Charbonneau. A group gathers around the meeting.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Piegan warrior
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Piegan Indians; Clothing and dress; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 35. Portrait of Piegan man facing right. He wears a quilled buffalo robe, necklace, earring, and small braid in his hair. Number 34 in this collection is a watercolor version of this image.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ahsch?psa Masihichsi, a Hidatsa man
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Hidatsa Indians; Clothing and dress; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 36. Detailed standing portrait of Hidatsa man, facing left. He wears a buffalo robe, decorated leggings and moccasins, and holds a gunstock-type club. His long hair goes to his calves, while the top part of his hair is tied in front of his eyes. Caption at bottom of page reads ""Minatarre warrior.""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Sih-S?, a Mandan man
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mandan Indians; Clothing and dress; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 37. Detailed standing portrait of Sih-S?, also known as Red Feather, facing left. He wears a decorated buffalo robe, earring, leggings, and moccasins. He carries a bow and quiver made of animal skin.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Psihdja-S?hpa and Tuk?n-H?ton, Yankton men
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Yankton Indians; Clothing and dress; Tattooing; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 38. Portrait of two seated Yankton Sioux men. Psihdja-S?hpa, on left, has long hair, necklace, and tattoo on chin. Tuk?n-H?ton, on right, has cloth wrapped around head and tattoos on chest.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Blackfeet girl
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indian children; Sihasapa Indians; Clothing and dress; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 39. Standing portrait of Blackfeet girl. She wears buffalo skin shirt, skirt with fringe, and leggings. She is barefoot and has a red mark on her forehead.

rdf:Description.dc:title: View of Fort Union
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Commerce; Horses
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 40; Landscape view of Fort Union. Pair of Native American men with horses in foreground left. Many people with horses, tipis in background.
rdf:Description.dc:coverage: United States--Fort Union Trading Post National Historic Site; Missouri River Valley

rdf:Description.dc:title: Blackfeet warrior on horseback
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Sihasapa Indians; Clothing and dress; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 41. Detailed portrait of man on horse, looking left over shoulder. He holds a rifle and carries a quiver. He wears a buffalo skin robe with fringe, leggings, and two feathers on his head.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Pioch-Ki?iu, a Piegan Blackfeet man
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Piegan Indians; Clothing and dress; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 42. Portrait of man facing right, wearing buffalo robe. His hair is bundled and tied on top of his head. His face is tinted blue. Pioch-Ki?iu is also known as Distant Bear.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Unidentified man
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Hidatsa Indians; Clothing and dress; Indian beadwork; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 43. Portrait of seated man, facing left. Similar to other portraits identifying Ahsch?psa Masihichsi, a Hidatsa. He wears several necklaces, some with fine beadwork, feathers in hair, and red face paint. His hair is tied in the middle of his forehead and into several fine braids.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Karl Bodmer's pencil, pen, and watercolor drawings prepared to illustrate Prince Maximilian of Wied's Travels in the interior of North America, circa 1833-1843
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Bodmer, Karl, 1809-1893
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians in art; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: The collection contains forty-three drawings done mostly in pencil, pen, or watercolor by Karl Bodmer. These drawings depict various American Indian tribes including village scenes and life, individual portraits, and landscape drawings of their route up the Missouri River.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 3 boxes: mixed media, including pencil, pen, and watercolor; 63 x 52 cm Drawings; Works of art Tiff
rdf:Description.dc:relation: Edward E. Ayer Art Collection (Newberry Library) Edward E. Ayer Digital Collection (Newberry Library)
rdf:Description.dc:rights: All rights reserved by the Newberry Library. Permission to reproduce in any format must be requested in writing. Contact Photoduplication Department, Newberry Library, 60 W. Walton St., Chicago, IL 60610. Phone: 312-255-3566 E-mail: photoduplication@newberry.org

rdf:Description.dc:title: Sketchbook cover
rdf:Description.dc:description: Inside cover of sketchbook. Front: ""Composition book, presented to [Miss K.M.] Mayer by [our] father -- August 24, 1849."" End: Sketch of a face. ""Nancy by Lautze.""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Interior of summer lodge, Little Crow's village
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Dakota Indians; Dwellings; Manners and customs; Saddlery; Horses; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 1. Sketch of lodge interior, with support beams, animal skins, and tomahawk or ax on floor. Pail hangs from a chain above a fire pit. Below this sketch is a composite sketch, featuring two details of saddle, and a robed sitting figure.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Elderly man
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Older Indians; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 2. Elderly Native American man, wrapped in blanket or robe, walks with a staff. Numeral 2 in upper left; ""42.55"" in lower left.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Camp and graveyard, Traverse des Sioux
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Dakota Indians; Manners and customs; Tipis; Cemeteries; Flags; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 3. Graveyard, with wooden fence and wooden crosses, at bottom of page. Above, sketch of a cluster of men standing near (American?) flag, tipis under trellis. Caption: ""Camp Traverse des Sioux. FM, July 16, 1851."" Bottom of page: ""Old French graveyard, Traverse des Sioux.""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Indian lodges, color notes
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Tipis; Dakota Indians; Dwellings; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 4. Watercolor of three tipis with trees and ridge behind. A blue figure stands among the tipis. Below, outside the parameters of this scene, a sketch of a chipmunk or squirrel.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kaposia, Little Crow's village
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Dakota Indians; Dwellings; Manners and customs; Indian women; Indian children; Canoes and canoeing; Tipis; Braids (Hairdressing); Villages; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 5. Village scene, with tipis and woodframe structures with hide (winter house). Hides drying on racks, a canoe rests on a frame, children play. Above this scene, three figures (one child, two women) with braided hair. Below, smaller sketches of a woman walking with a child; three figures in a canoe, one smoking pipe; one figure bending over near edge of water, as though washing hair. Caption: ""Kaposia, Litte Crow's village--June 19th 1851. Summer house -- tipitonkah -- tipi -- winter house.""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Wa-kaya Titonka
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Dakota Indian; Manners and customs; Tipis; Indian children; Dwellings; Villages; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 6. Village scene of several dwellings, some woodframe lodges, single tipi in center. People, children, and dogs included. Images on hilltop might be scaffolds for burials. Caption: ""Wa-kaya Titonka. Kaposia, June 19th, 1851. Tipi or Wakaya.""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Little Crow
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Little Crow, -1863; Kings and rulers; Dakota Indians; Clothing and dress; Tobacco use; Indians of North America Tribal chiefs; War bonnets
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 7. Portrait of Little Crow (Taoyateduta), hereditary chief of Kaposia band of Dakota Indians, seated holding long pipe with beadwork. He wears a split horn headdress with weasel tails, robe, and moccasins. Flag in background (20-plus stripes, eagle). Captions: ""Weasel tails. Duck head feathers. Porcupine quills. Duck. Red horse hair. Pipe inlaid with lead. Cha-tau-wah-ko-wah-ma-nee: the hawk that chases walking--alias Little Crow or Petit Corbeau. F.M. Traverse de Sioux camp. July 2 1851.""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Two seated figures
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Dakota Indians; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 8. Light sketch of two seated figures, huddled together and draped with blanket or hide.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Figures with dog
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Dakota Indians; Indian women; Clothing and dress; Dogs; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 9. Composite sketch of several women, seated and standing, one holding child. Below (and upside down), a dog. Caption: ""Traverse des Sioux, 1851.""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Playing drum
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Dakota Indians; Manners and customs; Drum; Tipis; Dogs; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 10. Four men stand outside tipis with dog. One plays a drum.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Saddles
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Saddlery; Dakota Indians; Indians of North America; Horses
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 11. Two detailed sketches of saddles on horses. Caption: ""Saddles. Traverse des Sioux, 1851.""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Draft sketch of figure from Drawing No. 13
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Dakota Indians; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 12. Standing figure wrapped in animal skin or blanket. He holds the blanket with one hand and gestures with the other. Preliminary sketch for main figure in next drawing (No. 13), ""Ye Council.""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ye council
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Dakota Indians; Manners and customs; Meetings; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 13. Group of six men seated on ground, one white man and five Native Americans. One Native American man stands and gestures toward the left. They appear to be looking at a map on the ground. Outline of row of tipis in background.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Feather ornamentation 1
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Dakota Indians; Clothing and dress; Feathers; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 14. Composite sketch of several heads with feathers attached to headbands or in hair. Also a sketch of seated woman with back turned. Annotated with numbers near figures (i.e. 42/29).

rdf:Description.dc:title: Feather ornamentation 2
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Dakota Indians; Clothing and dress; Feathers; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 15. Composite sketch of several heads (male and female) with feathers attached to headbands or in hair.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Standing figure with robe
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 57. Sketch of man, standing and facing left. He wears a blanket or robe, which is draped over his left arm, and a single feather on his head.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Standing figure with arms crossed
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 58. Man in animal skin robe, standing and facing right with his arms crossed. Two other figures, perhaps preliminary sketches, to the right.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Woman's face
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 58a. Face of woman with brown hair. A second sketch below of perhaps the same image. Both images have blue tint. Verso of Drawing No. 58.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Thunder dance
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 59. Two sketches of reclining man, propped on one arm or elbow. He has free hand to forehead, as if looking into the distance. At top of page, half a sketch of a woman. Dated March 11, 1857.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Unidentified man
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 60. Portrait sketch of man's face.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Men with baskets
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 60a. Two sketches of men holding baskets or bowls. At left, man faces left and holds basket in front of him, wearing blanket and tied hair. At right, man holds basket, wears blanket and two feathers in headband, and crosses legs at ankles. Verso of Drawing No. 60.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Interior of tipi
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Dwellings; Tipis
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 61. Small group of Native Americans inside tipi. One person lays down, as if ill or asleep. One person holds an object above his head and gestures toward person laying down. A staff with cloth or skin at end stands upright in the middle of the floor. Caption: ""Jan 11 18[57].""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Draft of feast scene
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 62. Group of men, some sitting, with baskets or bowls. Preliminary sketch for Drawing No. 65.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Seated man
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 62a. Sketch of man, leaning on ledge, holding a fan. He wears a decorated shirt. Verso of Drawing No. 62.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Dance
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Bow and arrow
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 63. Rear view of seated man. A blanket is draped over his shoulders. He wears an animal skin quiver, which holds arrows and a bow. His left arm is outstretched.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Side portrait
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 64. Profile sketch of person's head, with earring and braid.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Feast
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Food habits; Manners and customs; Clothing and dress
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 65. Meeting of many Native American men, some seated. Many carry bowls or trays of food; a cauldron in the center lets out steam. Man in foreground with ax and ear of corn. Another man wears animal skin quiver. To the right, a man holds a stalk of corn. Stalks of corn on floor.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Alex Ramsey, Governor of Minnesota
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Ramsey, Alexander, 1815-1903; Minnesota. Governor (1860-1863 : Ramsey)
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 66. Print reproduction of portrait sketch of Alexander Ramsey, Governor of Minnesota from 1849 to 1853.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Treaty of Traverse des Sioux
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Dakota Indians; Treaties; Manners and customs; Indian children; Sisseton Indians; Land tenure; Wahpeton Indians; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 67. Print reproduction. Large group of Dakota Indians and white men under leafy trellis. Two men sit at table, signing document. This was the 1851 treaty between the U.S. government and the Sisseton and Wahpeton bands of the Dakota Indians, which ceded most of the Dakota Territory (present-day Minnesota) to the U.S. The crowd includes children, an older person hunched over with a staff, babies, quivers with arrows, horses and dogs. Tipi village in background. Written on verso: ""Came with Col. Brown's letter to Mr. Ultey of July 30, 1927. Original in the Minn. Hist. Soc. Pub. in 2d vol. of Folwell's History of Minnesota.""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Frank B. Mayer collection of sketchbooks, drawings, and oil paintings of Sioux Indians during the 1851 treaty negotiations at Traverse des Sioux and Mendota, Minn., 1851-1886
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Mayer, Frank Blackwell, 1827-1899
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians in art; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Baltimore artist who traveled independently in 1851 to Minnesota to observe and sketch the Sioux Indians present at treaty negotiations at Traverse des Sioux and Mendota. In May of 1851 Mayer left Maryland and journeyed via the Ohio and Mississippi Rivers to Missouri, St. Paul, and Fort Snelling. Included in the images here are camp scenes (Indian ball-players, weddings, burials, dances) and renderings of Indian dress and equipment.
rdf:Description.dc:format: Drawings; Sketches; Sketchbooks; Works of art Tiff
rdf:Description.dc:relation: Edward E. Ayer Art Collection (Newberry Library) Edward E. Ayer Digital Collection (Newberry Library)

rdf:Description.dc:title: Attack on horseback
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Apache Indians; Combat; Clothing and dress; Indians of North America; Horses Spears
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing 1. Man on rearing horse attacks standing man with spear. Man on foot also armed with spear.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Woman on black horse greets man
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Apache Indians; Indians of North America; Indian women; Clothing and dress; Horses Spears
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing 2. Woman on horse in brightly colored dress, long hair, and silver belt. Man stands to the side in scalp shirt and yellow moccasins. He holds a spear.

rdf:Description.dc:title: White horse with accoutrements
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Horses; Saddlery; Apache Indians; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing 3. White horse with detail of saddle, bridle, and saddle blanket.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Two men with wounded man
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Apache Indians; Combat; Clothing and dress; Indians of North America Spears; Shields
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing 4. Two men with spears stand over wounded man lying on ground. Wounded man wears face paint and green moccasins, and his shield lies on his chest. Standing man on right wears scalp shirt and yellow moccasins.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Woman with basket and man with quiver
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Apache Indians; Indian women; Clothing and dress; Bow and arrow; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing 5. Woman with fringed dress and silver belt stands next to brightly decorated drum or basket. Man with quiver, bow and arrows and yellow moccasins with red tips stands behind her.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Group presents blanket
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Apache Indians; Clothing and dress; Manners and customs; Blankets; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing 6. Five people stand holding banner or blanket. They have long hair and wear bright tunics.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Warfare
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Apache Indians; Combat; Clothing and dress; Bow and arrow; Shields; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing 7. Two men aim bows and arrows at each other. Each has a shield. Arrows, some bent, on ground.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Three women
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Apache Indians; Indian women; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing 8. Three women in green shirts, necklaces, and fringed skirts stand with drums or baskets.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Man and snake
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Apache Indians; Clothing and dress; Snakes; Baskets; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing 9. Person with basket on back and long tunic waves hand toward large snake. Snake has yellow diamonds on its back, forked tongue, and a rattle or stinger.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Two men on horseback
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Apache Indians; Clothing and dress; Horses; Indians of North America Blankets; Spears
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing 10. Two men on horseback approach each other. Each has long blanket and spear. Drawing shows bridle detail.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Bison trampling man
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Apache Indians; Hunting; Buffaloes; Bison; Bow and arrow; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing 11. Man spears bison in neck while holding one of its horns. The bison is trampling a second man, whose bow and arrows lie on the ground.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Bison hunt
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Apache Indians; Hunting; Buffaloes; Bison; Lances; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing 12. Large black bison with tongue wagging steps in puddle of blood. Man with yellow moccasins and red ribbon around neck stabs bison with lance.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Bear hunt
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Apache Indians; Hunting; Bears; Indians of North America; Horses
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing 13. Man on horse tramples and stabs black bear. Man wears yellow tunic, blue head scarf and yellow moccasins. Two bear cubs near adult bear.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Two men on horseback with shields
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Apache Indians; Clothing and dress; Horses; Indians of North America Shields; Spears
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing 14. Two men on horseback, frontal view. Each has feathered shield, spear, yellow moccasins and cornered hats.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Man and bear
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Apache Indians; Hunting; Bears; Bow and arrow; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing 15. Blue bear with two arrows stuck in its back wrestles with man. Man wears scalp shirt, satchel, and moccasins. Quiver, broken arrow, and bow with broken string lie on ground.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Two men with shields on rearing horses
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Apache Indians; Combat; Horses; Shields; Bow and arrow; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing 16. Two men approach each other on horseback. Each has shield, arrow, bow, quiver, yellow moccasins and cornered hat.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Meeting
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Apache Indians; Rites and ceremonies; Manners and customs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing 17. Group of people sit at circular table, regarding two figures in the center. They wear, alternately, blue or red head scarves.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Two men in costume
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Apache Indians; Costume; Clothing and dress; Rites and ceremonies; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Two men with fringed skirts, red armbands, and black body paint hold small swords. They wear red and yellow headpieces shaped like a sideways ""E.""

rdf:Description.dc:title: Man greets woman on horse
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Apache Indians; Indian women; Manners and customs; Horses; Bow and arrow; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Woman with long, striped skirt on horseback is greeted by a man. He stands, holding rein, with his quiver and bows and arrows on the ground.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Woman with wares
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Apache Indians; Indian women; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Woman with long hair sits with wares, including a decorated skin stretched on a frame with fringe. She also has two baskets or shields and one piece of pottery.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Hand-to-hand combat
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Apache Indians; Combat; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Two men engaged in hand-to-hand combat. They stand, kicking and aiming daggers at one another.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Implements
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Apache Indians; Indian weapons; Shields; Bow and arrow; Lances; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Detail of feathered shield, bow, quiver, arrows and lance. To the right, a man's head with a decorated cornered hat (like a crown) looks at implements.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Woman and baby in cradleboard
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Apache Indians; Indian women; Indian children; Infants; Cradleboards; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Kneeling woman with long hair holds baby wrapped on board.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Frederick Gokliz ink and watercolor drawings of Apache Indians, circa 1894-circa 1899
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Gokliz, Frederick, -1901
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Apache art; Indians in art; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Unsigned ink drawings, colored with brightly-hued watercolors, of Apache Indians. The drawings were most likely made by Gokliz at Fort Sill, Okla., where they were probably collected for Edward E. Ayer by his nephew, Elbridge Ayer Burbank. Included are pictures of warriors, combat, and weaponry; horses and saddles; bear and buffalo hunters; women and babies; dancers; rugs and drums; a rattlesnake, etc.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 box (22 drawings); 35 x 27 cm Drawings; Watercolors; Works of art Tiff

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ancienne Lorette, Near Quebec
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Wyandot Indians; Indians of North America; Church buildings Church of the Annunciation
rdf:Description.dc:description: Volume 1, page 106. Depicts a view of Ancienne Lorette (also known as Vieille Lorette), meaning ""Old or Former Lorette"". It features the Church of the Annunciation, a church built for the Huron Indians, that formed the original colony. While the patronage is Our Lady of the Annunciation, it is commonly referred to as Lorette. Three Native Americans look over the landscape in the foreground.
rdf:Description.dc:identifier: Ayer 169.3 .W71 1842 vol.1, Canadian Scenery Illustrated, pg106, Ancienne Lorette_o2.jpg

rdf:Description.dc:title: Burial place of the Voyageurs

rdf:Description.dc:description: Volume 1, page 108. View of a lake as men wearing wide-brimmed hats carry canoes and large sacks onshore along a narrow path through the trees. rdf:Description.dc:identifier: Ayer 169.3 .W71 1842 vol.1, Canadian Scenery Illustrated, pg108, Burial place of the Voyageurss_o2.jpg

rdf:Description.dc:title: Carte nouvelle des royaumes de Tunis et d'Alger
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Peyssonnel, Jean-Andr, 1694-1759; Travel
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Ruins
rdf:Description.dc:description: Sheet 001. Shows region bounded by the coasts of southwestern Spain, Sardinia, western Italy, western Sicily and northern Africa, but most detailed along the coast and interior of Algeria and Tunisia south to the Atlas Mountains. Outlines Peyssonnel's 1724-1725 travel route, and includes list of 70 Arab ethnic groups. Margins contain 10 views of Roman ruins. Scale approximately 1:3,250,000.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 ms. map: hand col.; 320 x 880 mm Manuscript maps; Maps
rdf:Description.dc:identifier:
VAULT drawer Ayer MS map 30 sheet 1
NL000406_o2.jpg

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Coasts
rdf:Description.dc:description: Sheet 002, part 1 of 3. Shows west Africa along the coasts of Mauritania, Senegal,Gambia, and Guinea-Bissau. Identifies locations south from Cap Blanc through Arguin Island, Tres Grosse, the Senegal River, Enchorasco, Cape Verde, Gor?e, Portudal, the Gambia River, and the Tombali region. Depths shown with soundings. Scale approximately 1:1,148,000.

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Fisheries; Coasts

Shows fishing grounds along the northern coast of Mauritania in the region including the twentieth century sites of Dakhlet Nouadhibou, Ras Nouadhibou, Levrier Bay, Port Etienne, Arguin Bay, and Cape Blanc. Includes navigation notes A-Q and pictorial drawing of trading post buildings on Arguin Island. Scale approximately 1:327,000.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Plan du fort de lisle de Gore? et ses projets Plan du fort de l'isle de Gore? et ses projets
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Vernise, Ren?, active 1716
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Compagnie du S?n?gal; Slave trade; Fortification; Military architecture
rdf:Description.dc:description: Sheet 004. Shows the island of Gor?e off Cape Verde in Senegal, a French outpost important in the slave trade. Details fortifications and improvements proposed by P. Compagnon while working under the direction of Andr? Brue, director of the Compagnie du S?n?gal. Includes notes A-Z, &, a-y, and 1-12. Scale approximately 1:1,770.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 ms. map: hand col.; 515 x 709 mm Nautical charts; Manuscript maps; Maps
rdf:Description.dc:identifier:

NL000411_o2.jpg

rdf:Description.dc:title: Carte de la coste de Guine? tres juste au faite au grand point depuis la Pointe de Galines jusques au Cap de Lopes
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Nadreau, Captain, active 1715
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Trading posts; Slave trade; Coasts Gold Coast
rdf:Description.dc:description: Sheet 005. Shows the western and central coast of Africa from Pointe de Galines (later named Robertsport, Liberia) east and south through C?te d'Ivoire, Ghana, Togo, Benin, Nigeria, Cameroon, and Guinea, to Gabon as far as Cape Lopez (later the site of Port-Gentil). Names over twenty trading posts and forts along the Gold Coast important in the slave trade;pictorially displayed as fortress towers bearing European flags. Includes four inset maps, the first of which continues the main map at the same scale, and runs westward from Assinie to Pointe de Galines. The other insets are drawn at larger scales. The second shows trading posts in Nigeria's Calabar region. The last two detail the Gold Coast between Lampy & Komenda, and between Komenda and Assinie. Scale approximately 1:2,850,000.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 ms. map: hand col.; on sheet 564 x 748 mm Nautical charts; Manuscript maps; Maps
rdf:Description.dc:identifier:
VAULT drawer Ayer MS map 30 sheet 5
NL000412_o2.jpg

rdf:Description.dc:title: Carte des royaumes de Ivda et d'Ardre avec les confins des etats voisons
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Slave trade; Coasts
rdf:Description.dc:description: Sheet 006. Shows the coast and interior of Dahomey (later Benin) during the Atlantic slave trade, outlining the native kingdoms of Ouidah (previously Iuda, Juda, or Whydah), Grand-Popo, and Ardrah, the French and English forts at Ouidah, and selected other settlements, including Xavier, Jaquin, Porto-Novo, Papeguay, and Appa (later Epe). Villages shown pictorially. Also includes untitled inset views of a native king giving audience and a royal residence(?). Scale approximately 1:300,000.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 ms. map: hand col.; 449 x 706 mm Manuscript maps; Maps
rdf:Description.dc:identifier:
VAULT drawer Ayer MS map 30 sheet 6
NL000413_o2.jpg

rdf:Description.dc:title: Plan du fort de Iuda
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Fortification; Military architecture; Slave trade Fort Saint Louis; Fort William
rdf:Description.dc:description: Sheet 007. Map of Ouidah (previously Iuda, Juda, or Whydah) in Benin (previously Dahomey), part of the native kingdom of Ardrah,a region important in the slave trade. Combines fortification plans of Fort Saint Louis (French) and Fort William (English) with pictorial drawings of three adjacent native villages, a military chieftain with two attendants, and a wooded site identified as ""Bois ou les Negres font leurs fetiches."" Includes notes B-H detailing current and proposed fortification at Fort Saint Louis. Scale approximately 1:300,000.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 ms. map: hand col.; 506 x 706 mm Manuscript maps; Maps
rdf:Description.dc:identifier:
VAULT drawer Ayer MS map 30 sheet 7
NL000414_o2.jpg

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Fortification; Military architecture; Slave trade Fort Saint Louis
rdf:Description.dc:description: Sheet 008. Plan of Fort Saint Louis in Ouidah (previously Iuda, Juda, or Whydah) in Benin (previously Dahomey). Includes profile views of all four walls, and notes A-S detailing proposed improvements. Scale approximately 1:478.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 ms. map: hand col.; on sheet 565 x 369 mm Manuscript maps; Maps; Floor plans

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Bays
rdf:Description.dc:description: Sheet 013. Nautical chart of an unidentified bay on the northeastern coast of Madagascar, possibly Antongil Bay. On the chart, the bay is fed by two rivers on its west coast, and a third from the east. Shows 17 buildings comprising a French(?) settlement on an island at the north end, or head, of the bay. Also identifies the islands of "Jean Gomme" and "Isle Macambe" at the southern end, or mouth, of the bay. Scale approximately 1:90,300

Nautical chart and map of the region around Fort-Dauphin, established in 1643 by the Compagnie d'Orient on the southeast coast of Madagascar, and later the site of T?lanar?. Identifies the footprints of Forts Arguain, Bechon, Dauphin, du Nez, and Martimont(?). Nautical chart detailing the eastern African and Middle Eastern coastlines between the Cape of Good Hope and southern Iran, including the Red Sea, Persian Gulf, Madagascar, and various Indian Ocean islands. rdf:Description.dc:description: Sheet 050. Map of the Strait of Magellan, Tierra del Fuego, and the southern coasts of the Falkland Islands. The route of the Maurepas, commanded by ""Monsieur de la Verune, Lieutenant des Vaisseaux du Roy,"" is shown through Le Maire Strait and past Cape Horn in 1706. rdf:Description.dc:subject: Montagu, John Montagu, Duke of, 1690-1749; Bochart de Champigny, Jacques-Charles, marquis de -1754; Uring, Nathaniel Ships
rdf:Description.dc:description: Sheet 064. Map of the island of Saint Lucia with an inset (314 x 384mm.) of the port of Castries (previously known as Petit Carenage): Partie de l'isle Ste. Lucie. Includes six lines of text describing the failed 1723 invasion by ships under the command of Captain Nathaniel Uring, British deputy-governor of the island, acting under orders from John, Duke of Montagu. British forces left after negotiating terms with the French colonial governor-general of Martinique, Jacques-Charles Bochart de Champigny. Keyed to locations A-I and K-N; includes drawings of three ships. Scale approximately 1:177,000.

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Le Gardeur de Courtemanche, Augustin, 1663-1717; Coasts; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Sheet 100. Coastal charts of the Gulf of Saint Lawrence covering portions of southeastern Saguenay County in Qu?bec. The first chart ranges roughly 180 miles from the region around the ""R. des Hommes"" (i.e. the Aguanus River?) eastward past the Natashquan River, the Saint Mary islands, the Mecatina island groups, and Ha Ha Bay, to ""petite Baye des Rochers"" (i.e. Saint Augustin Bay?). Scale approximately 1:375,000. The second chart ranges about 30 miles from Eskimo Bay on the Saint Paul River eastward past the Ile a Bois to ""Pte. de Belsamont"" (i.e. L'Anse-au-Clair?), but is most detailed in the the Bradore Bay region, with drawings of Indian villages and the estate of Augustin Le Gardeur de Courtemanche, colonial ambassador and commandant on the Labrador coast. Scale approximately 1:275,000.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 2 ms. maps: hand col.; 425 x 599 mm and 1004 x 516 mm, on sheet 561 x 703 mm Nautical charts; Manuscript maps; Maps

rdf:Description.dc:description: Sheet 110. French copy of an unidentified English map probably compiled in the previous century; most place names in English. Illustrates the competing fur trade claims of Hudson's Bay Company and the Compagnie du Nord; identifies sites associated with the early European exploration of Hudson Bay, particularly the 1682-1683 expedition headed by Pierre Esprit Radisson and M?dard Chouart Des Groseilliers. Prominently labels the Nelson River winter camps of Radisson, HBC governor John Bridgar, ship captain Benjamin Gillam, and Sir Thomas Button (Button's expedition wintered there in 1612). Scales not given.

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Atlases, French; Manuscript maps --Early works to 1800; Nautical charts --Early works to 1800
rdf:Description.dc:description: Bound together in 1727 as an atlas comprised of 115 (i.e. 117) numbered leaves; includes sheets "71a" and "106a." Maps later disbound and mounted on cloth. All sheets are drawn with pen-and-ink and watercolor; most are folded. Arranged by geographic regions in the following order: Africa, Madagascar and neighboring islands, coastal India and China, Moluccas, Philippines, Strait of Magellan, eastern American coasts, South America, West Indies, Louisiana, Nova Scotia, Labrador, and the St. Lawrence River valley, ending with maps of Lorient and the Gironde River valley.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 117 leaves (121 maps and 11 views): ms., hand col. Atlases; Maps Tiff
rdf:Description.dc:relation: Edward E. Ayer Manuscript Map Collection (Newberry Library); Edward E. Ayer Manuscript Collection (Newberry Library); Cartes Marines Manuscript Map Collection (Newberry Library) Edward E. Ayer Digital Collection (Newberry Library)
rdf:Description.dc:rights: All rights reserved by the Newberry Library. Permission to reproduce in any format must be requested in writing. Contact Photoduplication Department, Newberry Library, 60 W. Walton St., Chicago, IL 60610. Phone: 312-255-3566. E-mail: photoduplication@newberry.org

rdf:Description.dc:title: Carte copie sur celle qui a t trace par le sauvage Ochagache et autres Carte trace par les Cris
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indian cartography
rdf:Description.dc:description: Tracing by Pierre Margry made 1846 from ca. 1728 manuscript map compiled for Pierre Gaultier de Varrenes, sieur de La Vrendrye, from Cree Indian sources, including Ochagach. Shows waterways in western Canada and the West (U.S.) from the northern shore of Lake Superior to Lake of the Woods, Lake Winnipeg, the upper Mississippi and Missouri.
rdf:Description.dc:contributor: Ochagach (Cree Indian); Margry, Pierre, 1818-1894; La V?rendrye, Pierre Gaultier de Varennes, sieur de, 1685-1749
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 ms. map; 617 x 1825 mm Manuscript maps; Maps Tiff
rdf:Description.dc:relation: Edward E. Ayer Manuscript Map Collection (Newberry Library); Pierre Margry Manuscript Map Collection (Newberry Library) Edward E. Ayer Digital Collection (Newberry Library)

rdf:Description.dc:title: Carte geographique de la Nouuelle Franse Carte geographiqve de la Novvelle France; Carte geographique de la Nouvelle Franse; Carte gographique de la Nouvelle France
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Champlain, Samuel de, 1574-1635
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Details the region surrounding the Saint Lawrence River Valley westward to the eastern end of Lake Erie; shows settlements and Indian villages. Detached from: Les voyages du sieur de Champlain Xaintongeois, capitaine ordinaire pour le roy en la marine. Paris : Iean Berjon, 1613. Partly based on information supplied by American Indians. Scale approximately 1:5,500,000. Relief shown pictorially. Oriented with north at upper right.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 map; 35 x 77 cm Maps; Engravings Tiff
rdf:Description.dc:source: Les voyages du sieur de Champlain Xaintongeois, capitaine ordinaire pour le roy en la marine : diuisez en deux liures : ou, Journal tres-fidele des obseruations faites ?s descouuertures de la Nouuelle France : ensemble deux cartes geografiques
rdf:Description.dc:relation: Edward E. Ayer Collection (Newberry Library) Edward E. Ayer Digital Collection (Newberry Library)

Red Jacket wears moccasins, a quill pouch, leggings, beaded garters, a red and white striped shirt, blue tie and shirt with collar. He also wears a large, silver medal.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Waa-na-taa or the Foremost in Battle, Chief of the Sioux tribe
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Yanktonai Indians; Indians of North America Tribal chiefs; Waa-na-taa
rdf:Description.dc:description: Plate 1. Description on opposite page: The sketch of this celebrated chief was taken in 1825 when he was in command of the Sioux tribe who inhabit a vast extent of territory on the Upper Mississippi in the northwest part of the United States of America. The occasion of meeting was at the great treaty held at Prairie du Chien, a small town on the Mississippi between a large body composed of Chippewas, Winnebagoes, Pottowattomies, Sioux, Sacs, Foxes, and other Indian tribes when the commissioners on the part of the United States were the Honorable Lewis Cass, at present minister plenipotentiary from this country to the court of France, and Governor William Clark of Missouri. Of the birth or parentage of this distinguished chief but little knowledge could be obtained by the author. The principal events of his life and which have gained him great distinction amongst the native tribes transpired during the late war between the United States and Great Britain, in which he aided the cause of the latter. At the time this sketch was taken, he wore on his head nineteen small red sticks, emblematical of the number of scalps which he had taken during this war; his breast was scarred by numerous wounds, and he showed the mark of a bullet which had passed through his arm. He was then apparently fifty years of age, but retained all vigor and alacrity of youth with very fine muscular as well as mental powers. In time of peace, his employment consists chiefly in hunting the wild buffalo. In this hazardous employment, mounted on a fleet Indian charger and armed with bows and arrows, he would sally undaunted into the middle of the wildest herd where, planting his arrows promiscuously, he would again rapidly retreat, leaving the victims of his unerring aim quietly to perish, weltering in their gore. The dress in which he was enveloped, as represented in the sketch, and highly characteristic of his favorite pursuits, consists of a buffalo skin dressed and ornamented with dyed porcupine quills. On his head he wears a plume of eagle's feathers with the pieces of red sticks before mentioned from which descend large strands of horse hair, dyed red. In his right hand he holds a gun, decorated with feathers and in his left a fan, composed of black horse hair. On his feet are moccasins, to which were attached foxes' tails. His height exceeded six feet and his appearance in his native costume was both singular and magnificent. In the background of this plate is represented the style and appearance of the native wigwams, or places of residence.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 print; 32 x 27.9 cm on sheet 50.4 x 31 cm

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tshu-Gue-Ga, A celebrated Chief half Winnebago and half French
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Winnebago Indians; Indians of North America Tribal chiefs; Tshu-Gue-Ga
rdf:Description.dc:description: Plate 2. Description on opposite page: This chief was the son of a French Indian trader, born in Montreal, whose name was Babtiste Grammont, by a Winnebago squaw, whom he married, at the same time settling with the tribe, who own an extensive tract of country between the Fox, Wisconsin, and Mississippi rivers, in the territory of Michigan, North America. Several children were the result of this marriage, of whom Tshu-gue-ga was the eldest. At an early age he was characterized by a crafty and cruel disposition; and one time, in a trivial dispute with his uncle, assassinated him, by planting his tomahawk in his skull. He was also one of the foremost at various depredations that were committed upon the white settlements; and the acts of rapine in which he was engaged were not unfrequently attended with bloodshed and murder, and scenes of the most horrid barbarity. He was at one time, at the head of his followers, the perpetrator of the massacre of nearly a whole and defense-less family on the Upper Mississippi, a short time previous to the commencement of the last American war. The victims were, a family of squatters, as the settlers are generally termed, consisting of a man, his wife, and three children. The husband was absent on a hunting excursion, when Tshu-gue-ga and his party arrived at the house, and demanded whiskey. The wife, not being in possession of any, and consequently unable to comply with their request, the merciless savages became so enraged, that they not only scalped her, and tomahawked the youthful children, but after rifling the house of its principal contents, set it on fire. The husband, on his return home, fortunately perceived the light, and suspecting the presence of Indians in the neighbourhood, secreted himself in a jungle until night-time, when he made his escape to the nearest American post. Scouts were immediately despatched in pursuit of the perpetrators of this tragedy, who, however, from their superior fleetness, evaded the pursuers, and regained their tribe in safety. At the time he was seen by the author of this work, Tshu-gue-ga appeared to be about forty-five years of age. His height was rather upwards of six feet, and he was remarkably strong and athletic -- so much so, that no chief on the treaty ground could contend with him either in running or wrestling. He was also very expert in fishing and in hunting, and has been known to bring down twenty deer in one day. From his skill in hunting, and his bravery, -- in which he had often distinguished himself, -- he was soon celebrated amongst the Winnebagoes, and appointed a war chief, shortly after which he endeavored to involve his tribe in a war with the government of the United States; but a timely arrival of troops on the Mississippi, in 1827, soon dispersed and quieted them, and maintained peace, in which they have continued to remain, with but little disturbance to the general tranquility. Tshu-gue-ga had three wives and a large family, to whom his conduct was as tyrannical and cruel as towards others. He was killed about two years since, in a drunken quarrel, by one of his band, to whom his arbitrary behaviour had rendered him very obnoxious. His costume was composed of a head-dress of feathers, with a crow-skin round his neck. He wore a blanket, and carried a spear, decorated with ribbons, beads, and other trinkets. One side of his face was painted black, he at the time being in mourning for the death of his second wife.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 print; 18 x 16 cm on sheet 50.4 x 31 cm

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kitch-ee-I-aa-ba, or the Big Buck, a Chippewa Chief
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Ojibwa Indians; Indians of North America Tribal chiefs; Kitch-ee-I-aa-ba
rdf:Description.dc:description: Plate 7. Description on opposite page: The subject of this notice was a chief of the Chippewa nation of Indians, whose reservations of land extended from the south-western shores of Lake Superior to the Upper Mississippi river. His character and prowess as a warrior were established long before his death; the recollections of his bravery and his valor are not forgotten in the war songs and dances of his tribe; and the name of Kitch-ee-I-aa-ba is a sufficient spell to rouse the warrior from his lair, and excite all his dormant energies. From his reputation, the author was extremely anxious to obtain some full particulars of a man who adorned the rough exterior of savage life by the exercise of those noble spirits and qualities which that unrestrained condition alone can develop, but could only procure the following particulars, which must suffice as an outline of his character. Kitch-ee-I-aa-ba was the son of Soo-cu-ris-kee, a Sac chief, who married the daughter of O-be-gis-qua, a full Chippewa chief. Soo-cu-ris-ke, his father, was killed on the 4th of September, 1791, at an engagement on the Miami river, near Fort Jefferson, when the Americans, under General Arthur St. Clair, were defeated by the Indians. Kitch-ee-I-aa-ba was then about twenty years of age, and after his father fell, took every opportunity of revenging his death by the indiscriminate slaughter of the opposing forces. At the head of his warlike countrymen, he was for some time an object of fear, and gained many advantages over his enemies, until he was in his turn compelled to fly. On this occasion, an incident happened well calculated to awaken the sympathetic susceptibilities even of an Indian heart. Kitch-ee-I-aa-ba loved an Indian maid, and his betrothed sharing with him the fearful chances of the battle, was severely wounded. He had already seen his father fall beneath the saber of the white man, but nothing daunted, his brave soul repelled all fear as it disdained compromise. He still continued to fight bravely, until the unerring bullet found its way to the heart of his beloved. At once, the madness unsubdued even by the reasoning instinct of the animal whose name he bore, agitated his whole frame. In one arm he bore her, bleeding and dying, from the battle field, following in the rear of the flying savages, while frequently would he turn and desperately face the advancing foe, until nature sank, and he fell under the afflicting burden. Sad and forlorn, however, he again rallied with sufficient strength; the din of arms had ceased, and he bore the inanimate body of his betrothed to a neighboring thicket, where scooping out a shallow grave with his scalping-knife, he deposited her inanimate body. Covering the place hallowed as the depository of the remains of the beauteous Indian maid with the fallen leaves of the forest, he smoked the pipe of grief upon the grave of one so pure, but so unfortunate -- the last sad honors that love requires from a savage votary. The author could glean but few other incidents of his career. When the sketch was taken, he was dressed in a hunting shirt and blanket. On his head he wore a bear -skin cap, from which descended large strands of horse-hair. He had round his neck a black handkerchief, and a necklace, formed of bone and brass wire. On one half of his face was painted with vermilion.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 print; 32 x 29.7 cm on sheet 51 x 31.5 cm

rdf:Description.dc:title: Prise de Newport par d'Estaing, 1778 ; Embossage de Ternay Newport, 1780 Embossage de Ternay Newport, 1780
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Estaing, Charles Henri, comte d', 1729-1794; Ternay, Charles Henry Louis d'Arsac, chevalier de, 1723-1780; Naval battles; Military operations, Naval; Anglo-French War (1778-1783); American Revolution (1775-1783)
rdf:Description.dc:description: Pen-and-ink and pencil on tracing paper; sectioned into 21 panels, mounted on cloth. Map of Newport and Narragansett Bay (R.I.) probably traced in the nineteenth century from an unidentified manuscript (in French naval archives?). Shows the August 1778 maneuvers by the French fleet commanded by Charles Henri, comte d'Estaing, against British forces during the siege of Newport. Also shows the fleet commanded by Charles Louis d'Arsac, chevalier de Ternay, as stationed in 1780. Identifies French and British ships, army camps, and fortifications, but lacks key corresponding to lettered land sites.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 ms. map; on sheet 988 x 556 mm Manuscript maps; Maps Tiff
rdf:Description.dc:identifier:
VAULT drawer Ayer MS map 237
ayer_ma_map_237_o2.jpg

rdf:Description.dc:title: Diaries: Morton, Ill., 1830-1886
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Roberts, John Montgomery, 1807-1886
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Roberts, John Montgomery, 1807-1886; Roberts family; Pioneers; Frontier and pioneer life; Farm life; Land settlement; Rural conditions; Emigration and immigration; Travel; Lithography; Manuscripts, American
rdf:Description.dc:description: 1831 volume. The diaries of John M. Roberts primarily focus on his family's daily farm life in Tazewell County. The Roberts family left their New York home in the summer of 1831 and travelled to Illinois by horse and wagon settling in Pleasant Grove Prairie. The diaries contain much information on the following topics: routine farm activities, farming expenses and property valuations, illnesses and medicinal cures, family births and deaths, local events, and weather conditions. Prior to settlement in Illinois, Roberts was engaged as an apprentice to a lithographic firm in New York City. In the first two volumes he describes the technical aspects of making lithographic plates as well as an earlier trip he made in 1830 to St. Louis and Illinois returning home via New Orleans. The collection of diaries also includes his first wife's (Mary W. Burhans) account of their trip to Morton in 1831 and his second wife's (Ann Waters) account of a trip to New England she made in 1859. A few volumes contain miscellaneous sketches of Robert's home and towns he visited in Illinois.
rdf:Description.dc:format: Diaries; Manuscripts; Genealogy Tiff

rdf:Description.dc:title: New England The Portraictuer of Captayne Iohn Smith, Admirall of New England
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Smith, John, 1580-1631
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Smith, John, 1580-1631 Sea monsters; Ships
rdf:Description.dc:description: Bound and folded opposite page 1. "Simon Pasaeus, sculpsit." "Robert Clerke, excudit." "London, printed by Geor. Low." Shows the coast of New England from Penobscot Bay, Maine, to the northern shore of Cape Cod, Massacusetts, with scattered illustrations of trees, hills, settlements, and churches. Scale approximately 1:985,313. Relief shown pictorially. Portrait of John Smith inset at upper left in oval frame with title: The Portraictuer of Captayne Iohn Smith, Admirall of New England; dated: Aeta. 37 ao. 1616; poem below portrait signed: John Dauies, Heref. Sea illustrated with monster and ships. Includes British royal coat of arms (motto: Hony soit qui mal y pense). Second state. Newberry's copy lacks portions of portrait and poem; portions replaced with facsimile.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Amerique Septentrionale, Acadie ou Nouvelle Ecosse aux Anglois, Annapolis Royal
rdf:Description.dc:description: Scale approximately 1:99,000. "Le tout tir des plans anglois. 1750". Probably compiled by French military engineers, but based on English sources. Details region centered on Annapolis Royal on the Annapolis River in Nova Scotia. Identifies rivers, anchorages, fortress, and individual buildings along the river valley. Drawn in two sections, the western above the eastern section. Relief shown with soundings and shading. Pen-and-ink and watercolor (green, yellow, red). Drawn on several pieces of paper pasted together as one sheet, sectioned into four panels and mounted on cloth.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Call of the blood Girl, Hoopa
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Freeman, Emma B., 1880-1928
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Hupa Indians; Athapascan Indians; Indian women; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Posed portrait photograph of a young woman. "Vol. 1, no. 3"--on back. "It has been rightly declared that 'an Indian never' forgets! This girl, clothed in the raiment of her people, is watching thru a lighted window an enemy of her tribe. One more look, then beck to where counsel will be taken. Falsehood and dishonesty find no lodging place in the people of the hills. She is on the invisible line between forest pride and modern civilization."--printed label on back. "102"--on back.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 portrait photograph; image 25.2 x 20.1 cm; mount 33.8 x 27.3 cm Photographs; Portraits Tiff

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Klamath Indians; Lutuamian Indians; Indian women; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Posed portrait photograph of a young woman. "Vol. 1-36"--on back. "A maiden's first lover has chanced to see a moment's pleasure with another. At a distance she stands with appealing, unresisting eyes, a touch of doubt and anger lights her face. She is pretty, young, and garbed in a dress of beauty. A dress covered with dainty shells and carved ornaments - presents from the younger braves of the tribe."--printed label on back. "144"--on back.

rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing No. 27. Dance ceremony, perhaps by members of the Mandan White Buffalo Cow Society. rdf:Description.dc:title: Plan de defense de New-Port
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Mullon, lieutenant, active 1780
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Ternay, Charles Henry Louis d'Arsac, chevalier de, 1723-1780; Rochambeau, Jean-Baptiste-Donatien de Vimeur, comte de, 1725-1807; Anglo-French War (1778-1783); Military operations, Naval; American Revolution (1775-1783)
rdf:Description.dc:description: Incomplete nineteenth-century map tracing of Rhode Island and Narragansett Bay. Traced from a 1780 manuscript compiled by Lieutenant Mullon, an officer in the French navy. Shows the French fleet commanded by Charles Louis d'Arsac, chevalier de Ternay, as stationed at Newport between 1780-1781, and the camps and fortifications of the army under Jean-Baptiste-Donatien de Vimeur, comte de Rochambeau. Pen-and-ink and pencil. Drawn on two sheets; map on tracing paper continued on larger sheet of light cardboard used as backing. Sectioned into 34 panels, mounted on cloth. Scale approximately 1:39,500. Limited relief shown with contour lines.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 ms. map; on sheet 705 x 1156 mm Manuscript maps; Maps Tiff

rdf:Description.dc:title: Call of the wild Hoopa
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Freeman, Emma B., 1880-1928
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Hupa Indians; Athapascan Indians; Indian women; Indians of North America Trees; Rivers
rdf:Description.dc:description: Posed portrait photograph of a young woman standing in a stream surrounded by woods. "Vol. 1, 19"--on back. "An Indian maiden has found her way into the heart of Nature's playground and stands on stones in a rippling stream of sparkling mountain water. She is calling to her companion high up the granite slope. Oh, for an hour away from care in this wilderness of wooded joy, where quiet and peace comes wafting down from God's great paradise."--printed label on back. "121"--on back.

rdf:Description.dc:description: Shows the Battle of Chesapeake Bay between the French fleet led by Vice Admiral the Comte de Grasse and the British fleet led by Rear Admiral Thomas Graves.
