rdf:Description.dc:title: Document relating to the descendants of Don Miguel Damin
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Damin, Miguel; Damin family; Actions and defenses; Real property; Property; Inheritance and succession; Indians of Mexico; Manuscripts, Mexican
rdf:Description.dc:description: Pictorial genealogy of the family of Miguel Damin, indicating names of his wife, his four legitimate children, and one illegitimate daughter, and their respective shares in his estate. Family relationships are shown by cords linking one person with another. Above the family tree are drawings of farm buildings, corrals, orchards, and fields which are divided into portions assigned to a certain son or daughter. Family names appear in Spanish, with Nahuatl words and hieroglyphics describing the cultivated fields. This manuscript, as well as Plan de plusiers proprits at the Bibliothque nationale in Paris, is believed to be related to litigation between members of the Damin family and Pedronilla Francisca.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 art original: ink and watercolor on native paper; 38 x 41 cm Genealogy; Drawings; Watercolors; Manuscripts; Works of art Tiff
rdf:Description.dc:identifier:

rdf:Description.dc:title: Voyage from Saint Louis in the territory of Louisiana and on the river Mississippi across the continent of North America by way of the river Misouri to the Pacific or western ocean in the years 1803, 4, 5 & 1806 Journal of Captains Lewis and Clark's expedition; Whitehouse journal
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Whitehouse, Joseph, approximately 1775-approximately 1860
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Whitehouse, Joseph, approximately 1775-approximately 1860; Lewis, Meriwether, 1774-1809; Clark, William, 1770-1838; Lewis and Clark Expedition; Travel; Overland journeys to the Pacific; Explorers; Discovery and exploration, American; Discoveries in geography; Publishers and publishing; Manuscripts, American
rdf:Description.dc:description: The most significant transcontinental journey in U.S. history, the Lewis and Clark Expedition was not only recorded in the journals and observations of the two captains, but also by four other members of the party. Private Joseph Whitehouse maintained during the expedition a journal consisting of extensive field notes bound in a single volume of three parts, the extant portion covering the period May 14, 1804 to November 6, 1805. Upon returning to St. Louis in the fall of 1806, Whitehouse had prepared by a copyist this new and expanded journal, May 14, 1804 - April 6, 1806, with the intent of having it published. This paraphrased version of the original journal includes a preface and fills in some gaps lacking in the original.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 33 cm Diaries; Overland journals; Travel literature; Manuscripts Tiff
rdf:Description.dc:relation: Edward E. Ayer Manuscript Collection (Newberry Library) Edward E. Ayer Digital Collection (Newberry Library)
rdf:Description.dc:coverage: United States, West; United States; Missouri

rdf:Description.dc:title: John Montgomery Roberts diary, Morton, Illinois, 1830
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Roberts, John Montgomery, 1807-1886
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Roberts, John Montgomery, 1807-1886; Roberts family; Pioneers; Frontier and pioneer life; Farm life; Land settlement; Rural conditions; Emigration and immigration; Travel; Lithography; Manuscripts, American
rdf:Description.dc:description: 1830 volume. The diaries of John M. Roberts primarily focus on his family's daily farm life in Tazewell County. The Roberts family left their New York home in the summer of 1831 and travelled to Illinois by horse and wagon settling in Pleasant Grove Prairie. The diaries contain much information on the following topics: routine farm activities, farming expenses and proberty valuations, illnesses and medicinal cures, family births and deaths, local events, and weather conditions. Prior to settlement in Illinois, Roberts was engaged as an apprentice to a lithographic firm in New York City. In the first two volumes he describes the technical aspects of making lithographic plates as well as an earlier trip he made in 1830 to St. Louis and Illinois returning home via New Orleans. The collection of diaries also includes his first wife's (Mary W. Burhans) account of their trip to Morton in 1831 and his second wife's (Ann Waters) account of a trip to New England she made in 1859. A few volumes contain miscellaneous sketches of Robert's home and towns he visited in Illinois.
rdf:Description.dc:format: Diaries; Manuscripts; Genealogy Tiff
rdf:Description.dc:source: Diaries: Morton, Ill., 1830-1886.

rdf:Description.dc:title: A pocket vocabulary of terms alphabetically arranged
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Ojibwa language
rdf:Description.dc:description: Anonymous English-Ojibwa vocabulary list from 1822. Words and phrases in English are arranged alphabetically, followed by their equivalents in Ojibwa. In addition, some terms are grouped by subject, such as the names of the months, seasons, kinship terms, colors, and numbers. Formerly part of the library of J.C. Pilling, who suggests H.R. Schoolcraft as possible author.
rdf:Description.dc:format: Glossaries, vocabularies, etc.; Manuscripts Tiff

rdf:Description.dc:title: Varias coplas, versos himnos en la lengua de Cobn de Verapaz sobre los misterios de la religin
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Cncer, Luis, -1549
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Catholic Church; Theology, Doctrinal; Hymns--Devotional use; Kekchi language
rdf:Description.dc:description: Canticles and hymns in Kekchi compiled by Dominican Father Luis Cncer, probably between 1536 and 1546, for use by recently-converted Indians of the province of Cobn, Alta Verapaz, Guatemala. Canticles narrate Biblical events, beginning with the Old Testament stories of the creation of the world, the expulsion of Adam and Eve from the Garden of Eden, the deluge, and the worshiping of false idols and the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah. Canticles for the church year from Christmas to Easter are based on the New Testament events of the life of Christ: the Nativity, the presentation of gifts by the Magi during Epiphany; the Purification of the Virgin; the flight into Egypt; the baptism of Christ by John the Baptist; the election of Apostles; Christ's miracles; the resurrection of Lazarus; and the Crucifixion. Also included are several canticles containing doctrinal material. The hymns to which the canticles are sung are indicated, and there is also a brief musical notation.
rdf:Description.dc:format: Manuscripts; Texts; Hymns; Canticles; Scores Tiff
rdf:Description.dc:source: Varias coplas, versos himnos en la lengua de Cobn de Verapaz sobre los misterios de la religin : para uso de los neofitos de la dicha provincia / compuestos por el Ven. Padre Luis Cancer, de la Orden de Santo Domingo

rdf:Description.dc:title: Souvenirs du Perou
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Peruvians; Ethnic costume; Clothing and dress; Costume; Manners and customs
rdf:Description.dc:description: Album of unsigned hand-colored lithographs, possibly dating from 1860-1879, illustrating the clothing and activities typical of the various social classes of mid-19th-century Peru.
rdf:Description.dc:format: Lithographs; Hand coloring; Calf bindings (Binding); Works of art Tiff
rdf:Description.dc:relation: Edward E. Ayer Manuscript Collection (Newberry Library) Edward E. Ayer Digital Collection (Newberry Library)

rdf:Description.dc:title: Carte du Cap Franois de Saint Domingue, de l'isle de Cuba, de la Jamaique avec le canal de Bahama, l'entre du fleuve St. Louis, et le pays de la Louisiane et les isles adjacentes, le tout depuis 16 degres de latitude jusqu'a trente six
rdf:Description.dc:description: Scale approximately 1:7,000,000. Pen-and-ink and watercolor (green, yellow, red, blue). ""Remarque le rouge est la terre aux Francois; le jeaune aux Espagnols, et le bleu aux Anglois."" Details lower Louisiana, the Gulf of Mexico, and the West Indies.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 ms. map: hand-colored; on sheet 336 x 680 mm
rdf:Description.dc:identifier: Ayer MS 257 No.1, Map 197 Carte du Cap Francois de Saint Domi_o2.jpg
rdf:Description.dc:coverage: West Indies; Gulf of Mexico; Louisiana

rdf:Description.dc:title: Isle Massacre ou Dauphine
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Ships; Islands
rdf:Description.dc:description: Scale approximately 1:200,000. Pen-and-ink and watercolor (green, yellow). Map of the French settlement at Dauphin Island in Mobile Bay as it appeared approximately 1719.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 ms. map: hand-colored; 164 x 217 mm
rdf:Description.dc:identifier: Ayer MS 257 No.2, Map 198 Isle Massacre ou Dauphine_o2.jpg

rdf:Description.dc:title: Plan de Pensacolle
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Fortification
rdf:Description.dc:description: Scale approximately 1:533,000. Pen-and-ink and watercolor (green, yellow, red). Map of the Pensacola, Florida region illustrating the capture of Forts Pensacola and Santa Rosa by French forces in 1719.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 ms. map: hand-colored; 171 x 227 mm
rdf:Description.dc:identifier: Ayer MS 257 No.3, Map 199 Plan de Pensacolle_o2.jpg

rdf:Description.dc:title: Plan du vieux Fort du Billoxi, 2 etablissement
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Fortification; Land grants
rdf:Description.dc:description: Pen-and-ink and watercolor (green, yellow, red). Map of the region around Fort Maurepas (also known as Fort Biloxi) on the eastern shore of Biloxi Bay as it appeared approximately 1720; later the site of Ocean Springs in Jackson County, Mississippi.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 ms. map: hand-colored; 164 x 215 mm
rdf:Description.dc:identifier: Ayer MS 257 No.4, Map 200 Plan du vieux Fort du Biloxy_o2.jpg

rdf:Description.dc:title: Fort St. Lois ou Nouveau Billoxy, 3eme etablissement
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Land grants; Fortification; Compagnie des Indes
rdf:Description.dc:description: Oriented with north at right. Pen-and-ink and watercolor (green, yellow). Map of Fort St. Louis as it appeared approximately 1720, on the western shore of Biloxi Bay, near the later site of D'Iberville in Harrison County, Mississippi. Identifies Compagnie des Indes buildings and land concessions.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 ms. map: hand-colored; 168 x 224 mm
rdf:Description.dc:identifier: Ayer MS 257 No.5, Map 201 Fort St. Louis ou Nouweau Billoxy_o2.jpg

rdf:Description.dc:title: Plan du Fort des Yachoux, concession de Mgr. le duc de Belle Isle et associez, detruit 1729
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Belle-Isle, Charles Louis Auguste Fouquet, duc de, 1684-1761; Land grants; Fortification
rdf:Description.dc:description: Scale approximately 1:2,920. Relief shown pictorially. Oriented with north at left. Pen-and-ink and watercolor (green, yellow, gray, red). Map of the region around Fort St. Peter (also known as Fort St. Pierre, St. Claude, St. Charles, and Snyder) as it appeared approximately 1722. The region formed part of Charles Louis Auguste Fouquet, duc de Belle-Isle's land concessions in provincial Louisiana, and later became part of Warren County, Mississippi, about 12 miles northeast of Vicksburg on the Yazoo River.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 ms. map: hand-colored; 217 x 312 mm
rdf:Description.dc:identifier: Ayer MS 257 no.6, Map 202 Plan du Fort des Yachoux_o2.jpg

rdf:Description.dc:title: Plan de la Nlle. Orleans, ville capitalle de la Louissianne
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Land grants
rdf:Description.dc:description: Scale approximately 1:20,000. Oriented with the northwest at the top. Pen-and-ink and watercolor (green, yellow, gray, red). Map of New Orleans and the surrounding region as it appeared approximately 1723. Identifies land concessions, land across the Mississippi River occupied by slaves, cultivated fields, and prominent buildings.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 ms. map: hand-colored; 340 x 455 mm
rdf:Description.dc:identifier: Ayer MS 257 No.7, Map 203 Plan de la N. Oleans_o2.jpg

rdf:Description.dc:title: Habitation de l'autheur sur le fleuve
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Dumont de Montigny; Plantations; Landowners; Dwellings Homes; Houses
rdf:Description.dc:description: Oriented with north at left. Pen-and-ink and watercolor (green, yellow, brown). Map of French army officer Dumont de Montigny's plantation on the east side of the Mississippi River as it appeared approximately 1730. Established roughly ten leagues (about 28 miles) down river from New Orleans, on site later forming part of Plaquemines Parish. Identifies main house, outbuildings, slave quarters, cultivated fields, and garden.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 ms. map: hand-colored; 168 x 214 mm
rdf:Description.dc:identifier: Ayer MS 257 No.8, Map 203a Habitation de l' auteur sur..._o2.jpg

rdf:Description.dc:title: Carte du Fort Rozalie des Natches franois avec ses dependances et village des sauvages
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Land grants; Fortification
rdf:Description.dc:description: Scale approximately 1:23,700. Relief shown pictorially. Oriented with north at left. Pen-and-ink and watercolor (green, yellow, gray). Map of Fort Panmure (also known as Fort Rosalie) and the Natchez, Mississippi region as it appeared approximately 1727.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 ms. map: hand-colored; 335 x 445 mm
rdf:Description.dc:identifier: Ayer MS 257 No.9, Map 204 Carte du Fort Rozalie des Natchez.._o2.jpg

rdf:Description.dc:title: Campement de l'arme Tombecbe
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Choctaw Indians; Chickasaw Indians; Indians of North America; Battles; Fortification
rdf:Description.dc:description: Relief shown pictorially. Oriented with north at left. Pen-and-ink and watercolor (green, yellow, gray, brown). Map of Fort Confederation (also known as Fort Tombcbee, Fort Tombigbee, and Fort York) on the Tombigbee River near the later site of Epes in Sumter County, Alabama. Details the 1736 occupation by French and Choctaw forces during their campaign against Chickasaw Indians allied with the English.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 ms. map: hand-colored; 177 x 268 mm
rdf:Description.dc:identifier: Ayer MS 257 No.10, Map 205 Campement de l' armee a Tombecbe_o2.jpg
rdf:Description.dc:coverage: Alabama--Fort Confederation; Alabama--Sumter County; United States--Tombigbee River

rdf:Description.dc:title: Campement de l'arme franoise devant un village des ennemis, les Chicachas le 26 de mais 1736
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Ackia, Battle of (Mississippi : 1736); Choctaw Indians; Chickasaw Indians; Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Relief shown pictorially. Oriented with north at right. Pen-and-ink and watercolor (green, gray, red, yellow). Map of the Battle of Ackia detailing failed 1736 attack by Choctaw and French allies led by Jean Baptiste Le Moyne, sieur de Bienville, against a Chickasaw village and English allies. Fought about 7 miles northwest of the later site of Tupelo in Lee County, Mississippi. Damaged: lacking portions of title and key.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 ms. map: hand-colored; on sheet 209 x 323 mm

rdf:Description.dc:title: Carte du Pouldu avec ses environs et la cte de la mer
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Austrian Succession, War of (1740-1748); Military campaigns
rdf:Description.dc:description: Scale approximately 1:19,500. Relief shown pictorially. Oriented with northeast at top. Pen-and-ink and watercolor (green, yellow, red, blue). Identifies military sites important during the British retreat from Pouldu, France, in 1746.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 ms. map: hand-colored; 223 x 390 mm
rdf:Description.dc:identifier: Ayer MS 257 No.12, Map 207 Carte du Pouldu avec ses Environs_o2.jpg

rdf:Description.dc:title: Concession des Chaoachas appartenante cy devant a Mgr. le duc de Belleisle et associez
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Belle-Isle, Charles Louis Auguste Fouquet, duc de, 1684-1761; Plantations; Land grants; Dwellings Homes; Houses
rdf:Description.dc:description: Oriented with southwest at top. Pen-and-ink and watercolor (green, yellow, red, grey). Shows plantation on Saint Catherine Creek in Natchez, Mississippi. The plantation formed part of Charles Louis Auguste Fouquet, duc de Belle-Isle's land concessions in provincial Louisiana. Identifies buildings, slave quarters, cleared fields, and canals.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 ms. map: hand-colored; 211 x 334 mm
rdf:Description.dc:identifier: Ayer MS 257 No.13, Map 208 Concession des Chaouachas_o2.jpg

rdf:Description.dc:title: Sauvage avec ses anciennes armes, arc et fleche; Sauvages dansant le calumet, avec le chichicoa a la main; Sauvage piqu, avec ses armes nouvelles
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Clothing and dress; Costume Trees; Bows; Arrows; Weapons; Pipes

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Musical instruments; Indians of North America Drums; Gourds

rdf:Description.dc:identifier: Ayer MS 257 No.16, Instuments of Music_o2.jpg

rdf:Description.dc:title: Sauvagesse femme de chef avec ses ornements et une evantail de queue de dinde; Sauvagesse couverte d'une couverture de plumes de dinde ou doije, et une micoanne; Fille pucelle ayant un pillon en main pour piller le mahij ou bles de turquie
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Indian women; Clothing and dress; Costume Trees; Feathers
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing number 17. Pen-and-ink and watercolor. Three North American Indian women in traditional dress.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Manierre et representation d'un cadre, ou les sauvages brulent a petit feu leurs prisoniers esclaves
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; Prisoners; Slaves; Torture; Corporal punishment Burning; Torture devices
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing number 18. Pen-and-ink and watercolor. Man tied to a wooden frame used for torture by burning.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Instruments de guerre et batons gravs, et l'arbre qui marquent la guerre declare d'une nation a une autre
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America; War; War, Declaration of; Indian weapons; Trees Tomahawks
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing number 19. Pen-and-ink and watercolor. Four North American Indian weapons and a tree marked red and black to signal a declaration of war between nations.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Boeuf sauvage
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Cattle Cows
rdf:Description.dc:description: Drawing number 20. Pen-and-ink and watercolor. Drawing of wild cattle.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Logement de l'autheur a la Nlle. Orleans
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Dumont de Montigny; Dwellings; Real property; Landowners Homes; Houses
rdf:Description.dc:description: Formerly numbered 21. Scale approximately 1:573. Pen-and-ink and watercolor (yellow, green, blue, grey). Plan of French army officer Dumont de Montigny's property in New Orleans, approximately 1733.

rdf:Description.dc:description: Land grant date March 29, 1799 to Captain Thomas Bell for three years service in the Virginia Line on Continental Establishment. Bell was awarded 1,353 acres in the Northwest Territory. On verso, land assigned to nephew Robert Gamble on July 21, 1799 and signed by Thomas Bell. Signed by: the President, John Adams; Timothy Pickering, Secretary of State; James McHenry, Secy. of War. Printed form on vellum with manuscript inserts; mounted paper seal of the United States.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Sarah Beavis her pamphlet
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Beavis, Sarah
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Beavis, Sarah; Beavis family; Frontier and pioneer life; Indians of North America; Pioneers; Women colonists; Colonization; Travel; Manuscripts, American
rdf:Description.dc:description: Narrative written by Sarah Beavis following her return in 1783 to Pennsylvania, mainly regarding her experiences on the Mississippi. Beavis describes her family's emigration to Kentucky in 1779, and to Fort Jefferson on the Mississippi the following spring. Noting the destruction of the settlement's crops and livestock by the Indians, Beavis then describes the company's trip down the Mississippi to winter in Natchez. On this voyage her husband and several children succumbed to starvation and disease, and Indians supplying provisions rescued the family from the intended cannibalism of a brother-in-law. Assisted by an old acquaintance, the family later traveled from Natchez to New Orleans where they boarded a vessel bound for Philadelphia.
rdf:Description.dc:format: Travel literature; Manuscripts Tiff
rdf:Description.dc:source: Sarah Beavis her pamphlet: James Beavis her brother and Ann Beavis her sister, 1783?

rdf:Description.dc:title: Indian petition to the general assembly
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Frontier and pioneer life; Indians of North America; Indians of North America--Government relations; Indians of North America--Wars; King George's War (United States : 1744-1748); Manuscripts, American
rdf:Description.dc:description: Draft of an Indian petition, April 1, 1747, to an unnamed general assembly (probably Massachusetts), written from a fortification called "Number 2 on Connecticut River." This document, which was to be signed by Old Town and three others on "behalf of others," concerns the Indians' participation in the frontier war effort. The petitioners request a reward in return for clearing the enemy from the western settlements. They also ask the assembly whether they should remain in the deserted garrisons or burn them.
rdf:Description.dc:format: 1 item (2 p.); 20 cm Petitions; Manuscripts Tiff
rdf:Description.dc:source: Indian petition to the general assembly : to the honourable house of representatives of , 1747 Apr. 1

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Southwell, Thomas
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Coasts; Boundaries
rdf:Description.dc:description: Scale approximately 1:6,840,000. Oriented toward the south. Pen-and-ink and watercolor (purple, yellow, green, pink, red, blue). Manuscript copy of a 1769 map made in 1783. Covers Caribbean area, the West Indies, the Gulf of Mexico, and the eastern American coast from South Carolina to the Oronoco River delta. Colored to show Spanish, French, English, Danish and Dutch colonial possessions; also marked to show islands taken in wartime (during the American Revolution?) by the Spanish, French, and English.

rdf:Description.dc:description: One of two component maps issued as part of: The seat of war in New England. Printed to the right of the main map from a separate copperplate with a separate but nearly identical imprint. Includes views of the battle, army formations, Charleston on fire, and the British camp on Boston Common. Includes key to streets and prominent buildings (1-12, A-I, and K-M), and historical notes on fires.

rdf:Description.dc:description: ""By an American volunteer ; with the marches of the several corps sent by the colonies towards Boston, with the attack on Bunkers-Hill."" Scale approximately 1:450,000. Prime meridian: Boston. Relief shown by hachures. Component maps (15 x 14 cm and 30 x 14 cm): Plan of Boston Harbour, from an actual survey -- Plan of the town of Boston with the attack on Bunkers-Hill in the peninsula of Charlestown, the 17th of June, 1775. Component maps printed to the right of main map from separate copperplate with a separate but nearly identical imprint. The maps of New England and the town of Boston include pictorial vignettes of American and British armies on the march, army positions, and fortifications. Boston map includes key to streets and prominent buildings (1-12 and A-I, and K-M), and historical notes on fires.

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Indians of North America
rdf:Description.dc:description: Fold-out map opposite page 415. "Made by order of Brig. Gen. S.W. Kearney, under instructions from Lieut. W.H. Emory, U.S.T.E. by Lieut's. J.W. Abert and W.G. Peck, U.S.T.E. 1846-7." Shows course of the Rio Grande River (Rio del Norte) and adjacent areas, including Santa Fe, Albuquerque, Taos, the road to Bent's Fort, ruins of Pecos, and the Gold Mountains near Tuerto. Scale approximately 1:644,000.
rdf:Description.dc:contributor: Emory, William H. (William Hemsley), 1811-1887; Kearny, Stephen Watts, 1794-1848; United States. Army. Corps of Topographical Engineers
